text: Bottle shared at Ratebeer awards show. 30/01/2016. Huge Thanks! A hazed golden orange coloured pour with a halo of white head. Aroma is funky tangerine, raw grains, funk. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, some age, oxidisation, apricot, tangerine, funky jammy fruits. Palate is medium sweet, moderate carbonation, grainy. Ok.
Im a beginner, so I dont have a detailed comment, but I like this beer a lot.

Batch 23 shared by Karl Meyer thanks. Aged for 10 years. Short white head. Clear amber color. Oak aged aroma with lots of vanilla. Light sparkling and smooth phenolic taste. Low bitterness and medium body.
Bottle at RBWG 2016. Thanks Andrew Borken. Nose is apricot and faint wood. Taste is lightly oxidized and papery. Hmm. Decent

Bottle. Hazy amber liquid with small to medium white head. Aroma of dried fruit, lemons, jenka, wood, raw sugar and lime. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes raw sugar, toffee, oak and light grain. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Solid.

Bottle courtesy of bhensonb via trade; shared with Linh, ken and Nica. Pours a deep murky rusty brown with no head or lace. Nose is straight wet wood and oxidation. Mouthfeel is medium to light bodied with notes of sweet bread, sugar and fruit. Pretty plain on the palate.

April 25, 2015. Bottle, batch 23, received in a trade with rfraga7, thanks! Hazy yellow with a medium sized, quite creamy, white head. Aroma is marzipan, sweet malty, oak, ripe tropical fruits, spices and hints of alcohol, some oxidized notes as well. Taste is medium sweet with some sugary notes, marzipan, tropical fruits, light bitter, oak notes, spices with a light warming finish. Medium bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation.

[4/25/15] Bottle sample at a tasting at omhpers place in Tyresö. Thanks omhper, AndySnow and hackobock for sharing great beers! Batch #23. Cloudy golden. Aroma of oxidation and some fruitiness. Sweetish flavor with oxidation  cardboard, fruits and a bit of wood. Medium-bodied.

How: Bottle.
Where: From hackobock, thanks!
Appearance: Hazy golden colour with a white head.
Aroma: Tropical fruit, mango, pineapple, some alcohol and spices.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Tropical fruit, mango, sweet malt, pineapple, vanilla.
Bottled, thanks hackobock!  Cloudy deep golden, mid sized. Oaky fruity nose. Sweet with medium-full body and rounded mouthfeel. Pineapple, cinnamon, sugar, oak and ripe fruit. Mildly warming finish.

Bottle shared with Tmoney99. No real pop upon opening. Pours a hazy orange golden color with no head due to the lack of carbonation. The aroma had citrus, oak, vanilla and some sweetness. The flavor has tangy citrus, some alcohol, oak, vanilla, hints of funk, very smooth and soft due to the lack of carbonation, I would not guess that this is 11 %. I would have liked to have had a regular Damnation next to this for comparison.
Bottle at Anchorage Sept 14 Tasting: Poured a golden to copper with white head. Aroma was oak, strong fruit, and light bready. Taste was very boozy with strong fermented fruit, malts, and oak.

"review from a few months ago, so details lacking. nice belgian strong/tripel (though a little dark and sweet for a classic triple). the oak aging was evident. fruity belgian yeast esters. very nice. only real flaw? the alcohol shows a wee bit too much."

Bottle thanks to Ontape ! Pours a hazy orange golden color with two fingers of sticky foam. Nose is sour oranges, rotten stonefruit, sweet caramel, vanilla, toasted oak, some hoppy citrus hints. Palate follows with a sensitive balance between sweet toffee tripel character played off heavy oak influence and some tart complex fruit character. Toasted vanilla lingers with a tart peach quality... pretty unique brew.

Bottle at home. Batch 69. Pour is hazy orange with a big white head and good lacing. Big sweet fruity aroma - banana bread, clove, cookies, doughy, sweet figs, orange peel, caramel, oak, and fruit peel. Taste is slightly oxidized, banana peel, sweet cookie, light spice, doughy, pepper, grapefruit, and caramel with a lightly bitter finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Pretty tasty, but seems to be a bit past its prime.

Pours hazy yellow with big soapy head and some lace. Aroma is beautiful soft full tangerine, light Brett, light coriander. Flavor is lovely sweet, super, juicy, vineous, astringent, herbal bitter, fresh light bread, and yeast. Feel is cooling and velvety while lively and deeply warming. So satisfying. A masterful beer. I like it so much more than the regular.

Bottle shared at the 8th Richmond Industry Gathering, 12/1/13. Batch 23. Pours a hazy yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma of pale malt, yeast, citrus, mild wood. The taste is pale bready malts, citrus, pith, yeast, mild wood notes. Medium bodied, slight sweetness, mild lingering tartness.

Bottle. Wow. Very different from the regular Damnation but you can definitely spot the connection. Looks like a RR brew in the glass, elegant. Taste is complex like fine white wine; lots of oak, but also fruit, Belgian yeast, slight tartness, more. Sweet but well-balanced. 11% ABV sounds right but it doesnt call attention to itself as in many strong ales. Didnt expect this to be a favorite but it kinda knocked me out.

Bottle (375 ml). Batch #069. Thanks to Scott for this one! Clear golden with no head and no lacing. Aroma is of candi, fruity notes, spices/yeast, alcohol, oak, some sweetness and minty notes. Taste is moderately sweet with oak, malt, light spices, candi, mint and a light warming (alcohol) finish. Medium body. Almost completely flat. Somewhat oily mouthfeel. Ok Tripel, but the absence of carbonation dont help what could have been a good beer... it decrease drinkability and gives to much place to the alcohol.

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks bro. pours hazy pale golden without a head or lacing, bummer. loads of candi and honeyed lightly caramelish toasted malts, minty dusty yeastiness, spices, bit of pear and apple juice, gently oaky leaving some coconut and vanilla traces - adding a bit more depth to the brew. low carbonation, medium body - oily, slightly sticky, moderate sweetness, relatively balanced herbal-grassy-spicy finish. this was quite nice and maybe would have been a lot better if at all carbed.

Bottle shared by tom10101, thanks a lot! Bottle opens up without a pop... Damn. Pours a light golden with no head and looking completely flat. Aroma is quite nice, though, with candi sugar in the front and yellow fruits and alcohol in the back. Taste is sweet and fruity, spicy. Body was medium, carbonation really low. Too bad there was no carb... this one would have scored high on my abbey tripel scale! It still drank really good in fact.
So... abbey style triple. Russian River has become a holy grail if you find their beers. If you find any of their beers you are in for a treat, floral, bread, hay
A rare treat for me... dont see much RR lately, but really appreciate it when I do... truly a classic, Belgian-style "kick your butt" beer. Love it! :)

Serving: 375 ml. bottle via trade with bytemesis. Thanks Mike! It pours a light gold color with a slight haze and a nice white head. Light floral and yeast notes in the nose. Beautiful balance flavor wise with a bit of sweetness, Belgian yeast notes, light oak, and a slight hop spiciness. Medium bodied with a dry finish. Absolutely delicious.

Bottle at home, batch 69.
APPEARANCE: light clouded blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: oak, alcohol, grains.
TASTE: alcohol, sweet, dry, quite aged already, over the top maybe?
Tasted quite good, but expected somewhat more for that alcohol...
Bottle pours a hazy gold with a large white head. Bready yeast aroma. Apple pears honey and grape taste. Slight oak taste, great beer.

375 ml bottle of Batch 69.
Aroma is fairly rich and malty with a lot of honey and light caramel. Light graininess and toasted bread notes also present. Medium light pear esters with a hint of a floral character. Light tropical fruit and new oak notes as well. Light alcohol in the aroma that becomes more perceptible as it warms.
Pours a cloudy dull golden orange with a small, moderately thick, white head that recedes fairly quickly to the shes where it lingers for a bit. Faint lacing and small to medium legs.
Flavor is fairly sweet with Moderate light caramel and honey melt notes with a touch of lightly toasted bread. Moderately strong fruit esters of post and banana along with some floral notes. Medium light oak character. Medium low bitterness with some alcohol spice in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium to medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth.
Overall an alright beer but this really isnt my preferred style and I am not sure that age has really helped this one, but I dont think age has really hurt it either. Im not quite sure how I wish this beer to be different but I know I wish it was changed.

375mL bottle at Toronado San Diego, pours a cloudy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out loads of Belgian yeast, light apples / pears, and dry fuzzy fruit skins. Flavour brings out loads fruity notes, Belgian yeast and fuzzy fruit skins. A lot fruitier than the base beer. I prefer the base beer, but this is a nice rendition.

The beer pours great with a nice mildly hazy golden straw color, a nice white head, and some lacing on the glass. The beer smells great with a nice blend of fruity, belgian sugar, oak, and corriander. The beer tastes outstanding with a nice fruity, oak, corriander taste a mild boozy finish that blends well together. The mouthfeel is great with the beer being perfectly carbonated, light to medium bodied, and leaves you somewhat sweet and lingering oak dry mouth. Overall, a solid oaked triple that blends perfectly together.

The taste is very crisp too. The moment it touches your tongue its almost sweet, but then the yeast takes control of your mouth. The yeast is the star in this beer giving it a nice bitterness which turns into a long dry finish. It has a very light malt profile and a slightly nutty caramel finish.

Upon further inspection of bottles.... can you believe my father in law brought a case of this up from Philly? pours golden, small white head. nose has whafts of flowers, grains, and very light clove. taste has a solid buttery cracker base that is balanced. flowers on the finish. body is light and drying.
bottle.   not a bad beer.  clean.  just not my thing. too much candy sugaresque sweetness.   some old wet musty wood.   not much to balance the sweet toffee, melon, candied sugar sweetness.   okay.

The pour is golden orange with a small thin head. The nose is vanilla, orange, light butter toffee and caramel. The taste is high sweet, low bitter. The texture is crisp and creamy at the same time. The body is heavy and the finish is long. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
The best beer by far, so far! Im pretty much hooked they have it at La Bodega, awesome store.

Cloudy gold, white head.
Strong, basement, fruit aroma...wood.
Flavour is heavy fruit and bold oak notes.
Very nicely done.
Bottle.  Musty berry and oak aroma.  Cloudy yellow with small head.  Musty over-ripe orange and lemon malt flavor.  Oak finish.  Spectacular.

Bottle share at DLD. Oaky, sweet fruity, and light Belgian yeast aroma. Cloudy straw gold with a huge white head. Sweet musty lemon-orange, strong oak, yeast, and coriander flavor. Medium creamy body. I liked this one just a tad bit more than the regular version, but thats probably because I really like oak.

Bottle, thanks danielcoor for sharing. My notes say this was batch 069. Hazy. Mostly golden, light orange hue to it. Thin white head, some lace. Citrusy, mostly rindy aroma. Pretty zesty tart taste, pretty nice. Light sweet taste, light bite. Smooth. Light lemon, good orange. Light funk. Medium to bigger body. More dry texture, very smooth. Long rindy citrusy aftertaste. Tasty stuff.. I think Id prefer some more tart character, though (I guess thats what Ive come to expect from other Russian River brews..)
375 ml bottle to snifter (Batch 23; thanks danielcoor). Looks good; a hazy orange with off-white lacing. Smells of Belgian yeast and oak. Tastes like it smells with a nice, dry mouthfeel. Enjoyable.

Bottle - batch 69. Pours cloudy amber with a large off-white head that slowly dissipates with great lacing. Aroma is fruity, peach, lime, a bit of wood. Flavor is very fruity, yeast, lemon zest, oak. Lightly sweet, zesty bitterness and some woody astringence. Medium body, champagnelike mouthfeel.

Bottle. Batch 23. Having this side-by-side with the regular Damnation. Not digging the aroma compared to the reg Damn. Hazy gold with a layer of lasting white, frothy head. Considerably better than the reg Damn. Doesnt taste overly oaky at first but the oak comes out as it warms. But a very nice Belgian strong flavor that could stand up to some of the better ones in Belgium.  The reg Damn has a nice flavor and has a lot less going on.

375mL bottle shared by mattyb83 pours a hazy golden/orange with a large white head. Aroma of peaches, honey, oak, bread, and slight Belgian spice. Nice and mellow easy drinking oak and mellow Belgian yeast. Not a huge fan of the style but this is well done and not overbearing.

750mL bottle, actual Batch #23.  Poured slightly cloudy peach with no head sticking around.  The aroma picked up pineapple, black pepper, and clovey notes with accents of oak and a little honey.  The flavor found a touch of honey plus bready notes at the core, with oak, black pepper, and Belgian-y yeast around.. tart fruit and tasty spices on the warm finish.  Medium-bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. really tasty stuff with great balance.. and the 11% didnt show up until much later!

Thanks Jason.  Batch 23. Pours to a glowing golden body with a thin wispy white head. Aromas of pineapple,  toasted oak, clean yeasts. Very balanced. Flavors of sweet toasted oak and pineapple with balanced yeasts.  Super complex. Medium full body. Really easy drinking for 11%.
Thanks Drew! Very hazy orange with a decent white head. Aroma of plums, wood, port. Complex flavors of fruit, wine, malt alcohol. Thin body and foams in the mouth. Unique and delicious.

375 ml bottle via BA trade. Batch 069. Pours a hazed gold, like tropical fruit juice, with a small white head that settles into a film. The aroma is weird- oak, sugar, plastic, wet dog, and sweet dried tropical fruits. Off. But the flavor is good- apricot, peach, pineapple, sweet malts, vanilla, and oak chips. Medium body, with a sweet, fruity mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Not bad, but the nose doesnt work for me at all.

Batch 069

The beer is transparent and golden hued, plentiful bubbles rapidly ascending to the surface. Even after a slow and careful pour, the head is a few inches thick, receding to a half inch and holding.

The aroma offers yeast, malt, citrus, spice, alcohol. Not picking up the oak characteristic I expected.

The oak comes through quite a bit in the flavor. A bit tart, with a nice blend of spice and floral notes. Lingering notes of wood in the finish. Well balanced and flavorful.

Alcohol content hidden pretty well. Warming finish. Medium-full bodied.

Overall, a really solid beer. Very glad to have this, as I missed batches 23 and 46.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-11-2011

Batch 23 thanks to Ryan D. You were on fire last night my friend. Another amazing beer from Russian River. Hard to believe this was one of the more tame offerings of the evening. Which isnt to say that this was bad. It was outstanding. Just more delicate, nuanced, and subtle than some of the other monster beers we tasted. Loved the mellow wood flavor to go along with the citrus and floral spice. Yummy.
Bottle 375ml @ home. Batch 69. Slightly hazy orange, long lasting  white head. Spice, lemon, some farmhouse in the aroma. Apricot, some wood notes, some vanilla. Excellent tripel.

375ml bottle of batch 69 that I shared with a friend. Golden yellow color, decent head. Smells estery and a whole lot like Damnation to me. The flavor was a bit of pear, belgian yeast, maybe I havent had Damnation in a while but this tastes a whole lot like what I remember. I did not taste any oak whatsoever. I will say that the alcohol was imperceptible which is pretty amazing given it was listed at like 10.8% or something. Nice beer but nothing to go crazy for.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-13-2012 03:21:44

Batch #69. On tap at Pi Bar in San Francisco, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy golden, with a small white head that fades to a remnant. The nose is tripelish with notes of oak, along with citrus, flowers, apple, Brett earth, grapes and just a touch of sour fruit. The flavour is somewhat sweet, with fruity, malty and wheat notes and just a touch of sour fruit. The finish is long and balanced with a slight alcoholic bite. On the palate, it is medium in body with a milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a great tripel with nice oaky notes. Very subtle and complex. It would be nice to try this one after some aging. 2012-02-15

Batch #23 thanks to a trade w/ Vendomebh1
Cloudy off orange color tall soapy frothy white head w/ no real lacing oddly enough, but it lasts for ever.  First scent was a sweet honey on bread hints of bananas, almost a little musty which I think might be the oak component a light touch of spice as well maybe a white pepper nicely complex.  First thought of the taste was wow the wood has a big effect on this one.  Theres a dry oaky taste especially in the finish past that theres a bit of a boozie character some peppery Belgian yeast tastes and a light hint of bread.  Palate is pretty average for a triple.  Overall a good beer, quite interesting.

This ale is a pretty tasty little mother...and by little I am referring to the body and bottle.  The alcohol is through the roof...10.75%.  The nose is that of a sour!  It is hugely effervescent and sort of tastes like a sour apple, malty, honey.

Orange/brown, hazy, beige head, good lace. Fruity, malty, light woody, lightly spiced. Medium body.

Bottle @ tasting. Aroma has big fruits, touch of wood and spices.
Flavour is light bitterness, big spices, touch of funky fruit. Nice one.
Yellow almost clear and big white head. Spices, lemon, very fresh. Easy drinkable, fresh and light. Pleasant bitterness. Nice. Dont get the barrel aging though. Thanks Menno/John!
Bottle. Hazy light golden yellow pour, huge white head. Aroma is very fruity, creamy, slightly funky, spicy and a bit alcoholic. Flavor is slightly bitter spicy with some fruis. Nice brew.

Batch 69 bottle at City Beer Store SF. Served in a small taster at fridge temp. Paid $18

A - Hazy and dark orange. Decent head lacing and legs. Head gone instantly.

S - Smells like a belgian tripel. Woody and bready with some spices and candied sugar. 

T - Tastes like a Saison. Some dark fruits with peaches and apricots dominating. Lots more bready yeast.  Some lemongrass finish?

M - 40% carbonation. Medium body. Finish is very dry and sweet.

O - This is solid. Not was great as I expected.

Batch 23 Bottle. Pours a very cloudy orange gold with medium frothy white head leaving spotty lacing and yeast flakes. The aroma is citrus and oak. Thin mouthfeel with a light oak yeast and fruit with a light dry finish. Easy to drink hiding alcohol well, a very impressive Abbey Tripel from Russian River.

Bottle thanks GT. Gold pour with lots of yeast flakes, thin white head. Aroma is nice, definitely some oxidization, mint, tripel yeast and bourbon are there. Taste is minty, nice belgian tripel flavor left, slight bourbon boozy finish. Good (batch 23).

Bottled. Front label said batch 23, but I realize now I should probablyve looked elsewhere for the "proper" batch number. Purchased in May 2012, would probably make it batch 69, then, right? Anyway.
It pours a cloudy, deep straw, with a white head.
Spicy fruity aroma, yeast, grapefruit peel, wood, melon, mangoes, jasmine, phenols, orange peel.
Dry, medium in both body and bitterness, lively CO2.
Spicy, fruity taste, malt, citrus, discretely woody, slightly sour notes, phenols, a floral touch, slightly funky, orange peel.
Quite elegant, not all that in-your-face that I somehow expected. Why did I only buy one? (2012-06-27)

I am looking at these ratings and I cant help but think that everyone drinks this and says, "oooohh russian river, I must suck their balls" this is a pedestrian tripel at best. The oak character is non-existent. Too high concentration of harsh esters for a tripel. Reg damnation is much better as it is truer to its form. Batch 69.

Batch 69. Hazy straw colored with orange tint. Big head and lively carbonation. Typical Belgian aroma with more fruit than spice, and notes of alcohol. Banana, grainy malt, metallic noble hops, hint of apricots and cherries. 
Medium body balances the alcohol bitterness. Some sweetness and both yeast and hop bitterness in good balance. The oak comes through just enough to be noticeable but not obvious. Nice bourbony finish. Impressive balance and complexity but maybe slightly strong. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to Greg from BBCK!!!! Lovely cloudy peach colored pour with a good looking frothy head. Nose is incredibly complex, with tons of sweet notes ranging from marzipan, almond, and vanilla icing to apricot, guava, and a gigantic melange of tropical and stone fruits. Flavor isnt quite as good, with less balance to the fruity esters and not as much accessible complexity, but still an absolutely gorgeous tripel.
Cloudy yellow orange in color.... Citrus, Belgian yeast aroma... Flavor is fairly tart and citrusy with Belgian yeast on the finish... Pretty solid...

Bottle shared with friends. Big thanks to Ed for sharing this bad boy. Slightly bitter but more on the fruity side with slight orange peel and zest. Hops make a slight appearance on the front end but is mostly a mix between malts and fruit.

pours a slightly dark dirty blonde with tons of head, big, fuzzy, fizzy, and cloudy. a bit of funk up front, with a soft oak and strong booze. a bit of fruit within the funk. bright and flavorful. the brett is very apparent in this. oak is hidden for the most part. touch of sweetness. lots of bite through out. assists in lingering flavors. decent, lacks some complexity though. Reviewed on: 11-02-2011

Batch 69 pours cloudy pale yellow with an effervescent white head.  Lots of head to this beer and very carbonated.  Aromas are bread and lemon with some wood.  Taste is lemon, bread, grass, and oak.  Body is medium and ABV is well hidden.  Overall, a good beer from a great brewery.

A - Pours a cloudy golden-orange color with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is mix of strong Belgian yeast character with some coriander and pepper, with some light fruit, citrus zest, oak, bread, and a touch of booze.

T - Starts off with some pear and other light fruits with some citrus zest, coriander, and other Belgian yeast flavors. Through the middle, the oak comes through alongside some stronger yeast character with some pepper and some farmhouse flavors. The finish is a mix of citrus and light fruit flavors with some bready yeast, oak, vanilla, and some booze.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Excellent Tripel with great balance. The oak is a really nice touch that adds some great complexity as well.
One of the few tripels I like.  This is lightly fruity herbaly hopped with notes of cider, pale malts and peppery spicyness.  The oak is subtle and nice providing woody sweet notes.
1500th rating. One of those apply triples. Not that much bread which like. Alcohol is very well hidden. Awesome brew

Arbitrary score 4/5 for Appearance, as nighttime conditions prevented correct assessment.  Fruity-Bretty, and oranges²; lactic acid. Brettanomyces - floormops included - reign in the mouth, with alcohol, and a delicate fruitiness. Some find sulphur retronasal. Very mild MF - certainly for RR - but quite carbonated. I cant quite understand what Vinnie intended with this. Its soft, but not 100% convincing.  Many thanks to both CarlK and Vinnie!

You tend to associate "oak aged" beers with stouts, but what about a Belgian Strong Pale Ale? Thats the concept behind Russian River Damnation Batch 23 - a unique twist on their regular brew where every 23rd batch is brewed with extra hops and aged on oak chips with a stronger final ABV and is consider a tripel. I cant say that this brewing technique made the beer any better, although the net result is certainly an interesting and unique beer.

NOTE: I had this beer in my fridge for literally seven months. Its possible I didnt get the same experience one would receive if drinking the beer fresh.

I received 375ml corked and caged bottle from a friend in the San Francisco area (thanks, Sean!). I poured it into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Bright orange hue, mostly translucent with slight haze, although fine, spastic carbonation is visible. Initially forms a huge, fluffy, white head which eventually settles down and does not leave much lacing on the glass.

Smell: Mild hop citrusy notes and light flower/candy fragrances. 

Taste: I had no idea what to expect with Russian River Damnation Batch 23. I thought the regular version was a good beer and an extra hoppy brew aged on oak chips could only make it better. I was surprised to find this beer was only as good as the original brew. More hops definitely are noticeable with a light citrusy flavor throughout the palate, especially of orange and a subtle tropical fruit juice cocktail at the core, too. A quick hop bite through the middle with a kiss of candy sweetness on the finish. Theres a mild vanilla taste in there as well, likely due to the oak chips. 

But much like the regular Damnation, this beer isnt quite as complex as youd think. Its these same few flavors repeated, without much development. Thankfully the alcohol is extremely well masked and the sweetness is never sticky or cloying. I did get a minor hint of black pepper, but nothing comparable to a Chimay White, etc. Its satisfying for sure, but for such a unique and rare beer youd expect something a little more impressive. 

Drinkability: The mouthfeel is quite thin and crisp like an authentic Belgian tripel. The clean aftertaste is a nice change of pace, although its not what I would consider extremely smooth since carbonation does get stuck in the throat after each swig.  While I wasnt completely wowed by the palate of Russian River Damnation Batch 23, I definitely have to give it kudos for being so drinkable for such a hefty brew. At 10.75% ABV is there no alcohol presence here at all. Just a slight warmth in the throat, but no alcohol distraction in the palate.

Bottle from Richard.  Yellow color pour with a white head.  Smell is oaky, hints of citrus, and a little bit of hops.  Taste is smooth, light, flly carbonated with no alcohol. I am not a fan of trpels but good lord this is good.  Vinnie is a master brewer.  Easily the best trpel out there.

Batch 69, bought Jan 30, 2012. Pours hazy golden amber, fluffy white head dissipates to a fine lacing edging the glass. Aromas of fruity esters, orange peel, oak, cloves, citric fruits, pepper and with a slight funkyness on the nose. Flavours follow the aromas with a great spicy, peppery nose, orange peel/pith, cloves and a slight fennel seed undertone. Great, subtle carbonation tickles the tongue. Smooth, bittersweet, creamy, long & drying finish. Alcohol is very well hidden.

Originally reviewed: 3/12/12. Had this one on-tap at Tonys Darts Away in Burbank. 

Bartender poured into this into a tall tulip glass, revealing a slightly hazy golden hue. A finger-widths worth of creamy foam capped it off. The nose is sharp with Belgian yeast, lemon zest, faint tangerine. The mouthfeel was much smoother than anticipated, aided by the oak chips, no doubt. Light bubbly finish. Light hoppy flavors meld well with the yeast character, and then finishes with a mildly-tart citrus snap. Spicy lemons come to mind with this beer. I liked it quite a bit. RR has made another standout brew here. Glad I had the opportunity.

Bouteille de 375 ml, batch 69. Merci beaucoup à Dany et Marie-France. Arômes de levure très citronnés et rappelant le pain frais. Légère touche de houblon citronné. Robe blonde pâle et légèrement trouble, très belle mousse et effervescence active. En bouche, la bière montre toute son élégance, avec un très bel équilibre entre un malt croustillant et un caractère de levure belge tout en retenue. Le houblon contribue également des notes citronnées et épicées. Le chêne ne se manifeste quen finale, apportant une légère sécheresse et un soupçon de vanille. Finale alcoolisée et très délicatement amère. Une très belle interprétation américaine dune triple belge, parfaitement exécutée.

Poured into a snifter. Batch 69. Big thanks to Bilbosnuts for this.

4.5 A: Hazed dark orange brown color. Two fingers of frothy white head. Retention is very good and lots of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Nice sugary, spicy tripel. Lots of pepper. Hay and bready malts with peach and apple fruitiness. Oaky underneath with a mild vanilla.

4.0 T: Loads of pepper and maybe a touch of clove underneath. Big fruitiness with peach and apple showcased and a hint of banana. Oaky with a mild vanilla and note of supple tannins. Quite tasty.

4.0 M: Lighter medium to medium body. Plenty of spritzy carbonation, maybe a bit too much. Nice creaminess and super smooth.

4.5 D: Definitely a solid tripel. Not the most complex, but great flavors that come together well.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-11-2012 21:50:17
Delicious. Aroma is oakey with a fruit.spine.  Hazy orange colour with a thick head.  Plummy flavour with many oak notes.  Sweet, but not too sweet finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 375ml. bottle, from batch 69.  Thanks Mike L.  Pours a hazy golden color, with a white head. Aroma is floral hops and some citrus. Taste is fruity (sweet), spicy, and hoppy. Finish is dry, bitter and warm.
Bottled.  Poured a gorgeous gold with a large head. Winey fruity notes, lemon,lime, sour taste.  Couldnt really dtect the oak but who cares? Real dgood.

375 ML Bottle. Pours a hazy pale with a nice dense generous head. Good lacing.
Aromas of oak and floral with citrus, long lasting dry finish that hides the 11%. alcohol  well. All around solid beer!

Bottle: Poured a hazy bright golden color ale with a super huge foamy had with excellent retention and some very good lacing. Aroma which consists of citrus and floral hops are well balanced against the sweet notes of the malt bill. Taste is a great mix between some citrus and floral hoppy notes and some semisweet malt notes. Oak is very subtle but seems to bring a rounder taste at the end. Yeast strain a somewhat fruity and can be detected. Body is full with great conditioning and some excellent carbonation with no apparent alcohol. This is a great improvement IMO over the regular version which is just too fruity.

Pours with a generous head that does go down but never disappears. The best of their aged beers from RR that I have tasted so far. Not overpoweringly sour but is tangy for sure, not too carbonated but you can feel it, the bitterness hits at the end as you feel the warmth of the alcohol going down. Excellent to say the least a robust taste that is smooth. Hazy blone in appearance and cloudy.

Tap at RR Brewpub. It pours hazy blonde, with a foamy white head. The nose is apple, pear, melon, hay, straw and dough. The taste is melon, pear, red apple, tinned nectarine, honey, alcohol warmth, hay, spice, straw and dough, with a tangy-dry finish. Initially sweet, then balances out to a more savoury finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Definitely an improvement on the standard Damnation.

375 ml bottle. Batch #069. Brewed on 27.07.2011. Bottled on 01.09.2011.	
Pours hazy golden color with small head. Aroma of soap, citrus, yeast, fruits and spices. Flavor of citrus, apricot, spices, yeast, distant glue notes, ripe fruits and some herbs. Quite balanced tripel.
3435

375 ml bottle. Batch 069, brewed on 27.7.2011, bottled on 1.9.2011.
Pours a hazy golden colour with a white head. Aroma of sweet ripe fruits such as apricot and banana and some wood. Flavour of sweet ripe fruits, caramel malts, some hops, yeast, stinging oak and bitter hops. Some alcohol as well. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, warming finish with loads of stinging oak and ripe fruits. Not really a fan of these oak chip aged beers as the oak tends to sting too much. This beer has the same problem, but the fruitiness here smoothens the flavour a bit.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2012 
37,5 cl bottle @ home. Batch #069: French saison yeast, 10,75% ABV. Brewed 27.08.2011, bottled 01.09.2011.
Aroma has lots of soapy citrus and some apricot. Flavour is sweetish with apricot and some citrus. Also hints of glueish notes and vanilla. Hints of alcohol in the finish when this warms up. Rich and excellent tripel!

375ml bottle from City Beer, San Francisco, CA
Batch 069, 10.75% ABV, Brewed on 7/27/2011, bottled on 9/1/2011 (French Saison Yeast) - Pours orange with a bubbly white head. Soapy aroma with notes of citrus, lemon, spices and slight hints of oak. Taste is fruity and spicy with notes of citrus, lemon, oak, vanilla, wood, berries and slight tartness. Finish is slightly bitter and fruity with some glue notes. Alcohol burns through slightly in the finish. Well balanced and tasty tripel.

This.  Is.  Amazing.  Aroma is standard Belgian golden... yeast, hops, sweet malt.  Flavor is an explosion of sweet malts, golden raisin, and juicy citrus.  Finish is just a repetition of the initial flavor bomb... and it lingers and lingers.  Amazing beer.

This poured a semi cloudy lighter golden color with a white head. Aroma was estery, yeast, some bretty notes, oak, and candy sweetness. Flavor was mildly tart and bretty, then follows into nice spicey notes and oak, and finishes very very dry. Carbonation is spot on. I love RR!
Bottle. Hazy golden color, massive fluffy white head, decent lacing. Aroma of pear, subtle pineapple, white pepper. Taste is pepper, straw. Not bad.

Tap at Russian River. Pours a clear golden with a smaller white head. Nose is intensely estery with pear, white grapes, and pale ale grist. Taste is thick, chewy, sliced pear, white grapes, mild paper. Good- but not a favorite. Palate is lacking: dusty, powdery, papery. Big esters are unnecessary. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2015 Tap at RR, gold pour, white head, nose is sweet, taste is barnyard, smooth, amazing belgian

38cl, Batch 69, at 10.75%Vol, as Damnation Batch 23, exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, spicy/sweet and slightly alcoholic/fruity, not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good brew, yet very expensive!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 Pour out of 375 mL bottle, big thanks to Caleb and Jeff/Bacterial for the pour.  Nice hazy yellow pour with nice white head, aroma has notes of biscuit, yeast, slight bready lemon, hints of oak, toffee, nice pils malt.  Taste is a nice mix of slight oak, biscuit, some slight toffee, slight yeasty notes, finishing fairly dry.  Nicely done.
Good golden ale. Can smell the oak barrel. Can taste the hint of whiskey or somthing. Idk where they get the barrels

hazy orange-golden with small eggy head. slightly sweeter than normal. Citrusy notes, fruity malt along with alcohol. Bitter slight alcoholic finish. 
indeed a stronger slightly more complex version of damnation.

Still very nice!

Batch 23 sample at Central Waters release party.  Hazy and a tad more yellow-amber than the original version.  Aroma of citrus, acidic tang, light vanilla, mild spice, and faint oak.  Flavor is tart lemon citrus, some spicy hop bitterness in the middle, and vanilla and light oak in the finish.  Carbonation makes palate slightly creamy.  Crisp tart finish.  Only slightly better than original.

Bottle, 375ml, batch 69.
Pours a cloudy orange with a bit white head.
Smells primarily of phenols, with some citrus, tartness, and spice.
Taste is spicy, with a heavy sweetness, some brett sourness, fruitiness, and lots of malt.
Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Creamy texture. Finishes tingly, with some fruity tartness.
Quite tasty.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2012 Rerate from bottle. $10.99 375ml bottle of  Batch 69.  Hazy golden amber with huge effervescent head.  Big pop from cork.  Hazy orange amber. Nose is bright citrussy yeast, lemon and tangerine.  Sweet tart funkiness.   Mouth explodes with lively burst of foam as you drink it.  A mouthfull.  Big sharp citrus and alcohol.  Tart and lively.  Beautiful beer. Up from 3.9 
 Tap at obriens. Hazy amber with no lace. Nose lightly tart. Taste is light and high mid but full. Big mouth full and bitter hint out back. Gooey back. Full and light with tart hints. Good.

bottle. courtesy of the Monks crew from SF at Beer Bar summit. Golden pour. peachy, apricot aromas & flavors, tart & sweet triple notes, lighter oak, good amount of funk. Very nice stuff. Real Nice treat

Sampled at the Day After Thanksgiving Tasting 2011.  Very small sample poured a deep clear golden hue.  Very bitter triple. A little yeasty funk.  Honestly, I didnt really find it all that appealing.
pours a off yellow with a large white head. Aroma is a bit like a lemon or maybe floral. Flavor is sweet and oaked. Finishes with a bit of lemon/bannana.

My bottle at Stone Brewing Bistro and Gardens.  Yeasty aroma mostly.  Starts sweet and then finishes bitter. Funkier as it warms. Hits the style and also funkier than the style. Would be much better with food. 375 ml is sufficient without it. Enormous head.

On tap at City Beer. Served in a snifter. Pours hazy golden yellow with small white head. Aromas of lemon, clove, banana, and a bit of wood. Flavors of peach, lemon, banana, clove, some bitterness in there as well. Mouthfeel is soft and this is extremely drinkable. Wow really nice beer.
golden pour, sparkling, with huge white head. aroma of clove, pepper, yeast, spice, and heat. flavor is similar to aroma with added lemon zest...decent

Kind of a tan color with orange hues, cloudy, with a nice white head and good lacing.  Smells is really nice, Belgian yeast and spices, citrus, light to mid fruits, banana, clove, a tinge of woodiness, and a healthy dose of funk.   Taste follows the smell, less funky than I imagined it would be from the smell, subtle woody notes, great Belgian yeast flavors, enough hoppiness to balance it all out, just a tinge of alcohol.  Body is pretty rich and full, plenty of carbonation, alcohol is present but not very noticeable.  
Another damn fine beer from RR.  What else needs to be said?

pours clear golden, lots of carbonation, white dense head. Nose of sweet esters, sour apple, oak, vanilla. sweet esters, banana, honey, lemon citrus and floral hop bitterness. pillowy carbonation. champagne, rich texture. complex. long, acidic bitterness with subtlety and sourness.

Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy straw color with TONS of head.  This was nearly a gusher.  Aroma is some hay and belgian yeast.  I was not a huge fan of this beer.  A bit too much bitterness and barnyard in this one.

Poured to a snifter.
Pours a hazy yellow straw color with a thin fizzy white head. 
Aroma, big fruity nose, citrus, oak, and yeast.
Flavor is pretty sweet, peach, and apricote with a subtle citrus finish.
Pretty light body with moderately high carbonation. 
Overall pretty nice, light and refreshing. Not that complex but drinkable.

Pours a hazy golden orange color with a two finger frothy white head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Sporadic chunks of soapy lacig left behind. 

Sweet, slightly earthy aroma wih lots of estery light fruit notes, toasted oak, vanilla and earthy hops. Hints of apple and lead along with some pine and champagne yeast. 

Medium bodied with some soft carbonation up frot along with a champagne like efervesence that gives off hints of bready yeast and light fruit esters. Lots of sweet apple and pear along with slight booze and spice but this is nicely mellowed out by the oak presence. Not overly dry or toasted with hints of coconut and vanilla that nicely masks the high ABV. Some virgin oak beers taste like charred tooth picks but here it is nicely integrated into the flavor of the base beer. Complex, flavorful and dangerously drinkable.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Slightly hazy light straw-orange body, thick puffy off-white head. Lots of clove in the nose, which is bitter, dusty, and sweet with candy corn, a touch of bubblegum, white grape, and pear. Very sharply carbonated, dry body with abundant clove and alcohol heat, somewhat balanced by light fruit (primarily white grape and pear) and crackers. Surprisingly dry.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate oak, lemon peel, banana, apple, and a hint of vanilla. It pours a cloudy golden-orange with a small white head. The flavor starts with apple and yeast. The finish has banana, vanla, and light oak. Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 A - pours clear crisp gold. High head with nice lacing. 

S - Aromas of bready Belgian yeast and oakyness, with note of  light apple. Hints of honey and flowers.

M - med body with high carb. Nice mf slightly sour and bitter. 

T - Nice Belgian yeasts on the nose, bready. Notes of  lemon, honey, apricots. Subtle hint of pepper. Tannins very subtle in this brew. Oakiness is subtle and welcome.  Well balanced.

O -Good belgian beer. Subtlely complex. drinkable.

7-

Bottle courtesy of Sebowski from TBS - thanks.  Poured a nice goldenrod and had a nice head on it.  Had a nice spicy feel to it, with perhaps a little peach/apricot sweetness.  Reminded me a lot of La Fin Du Monde, which was good.
Bottle shared by Steve at my house. Pours gold with white head. Nose/taste of oak, hops, fruity esters, yeast and lemon cake. Medium body. (Blended well with Sour Bitch by Mikkeller)

Served from a 375 mL bottle from Barons. The appearance is a crystal clear golden hue. Lots of flowing bubbles lead up to a good size dense white foam head. The aromas are full of yeast and bread notes. White peach, champagne, The flavors are yeasty, with honey, white peach, drying raw oak, flower pedals, creamy orange. Very carbonated and lively, a bit too much and it almost hurts the stomach. Overall a flavorful and well done beer. I expected something different from the oak but thats okay. Not overly a style I love but a fine beer that grew on me through the bottle.

Bottle @ home next to the normal version, courtesy of wavers1. Thanks a bunch. The cork shot off like a motherfucker and poured with a huge head. Hazy, golden orange appearance that poured a huge foamy, off white head. Belgian yeasty, big citrusy, orange, somewhat tart, lightly funky aroma. Somewhat spicy, Belgian yeasty, orange citrusy, lightly woody, somewhat funky flavor. More interesting than the normal version and actually fairly different.

Draft at RRBC and from bottle. Pretty moonlit hazed honey-gold and nice lacing and head. Immediately smells sweet and yeasty in draft version. Less so from the bottle, where it is dryer and more refined. Still overt Belgian yeast character but subtler with the bottle conditioning. The bottle version is mellower but still tastes too sweet for me, with again the overt Belgian yeast character not fermented or dry enough. So much like what happens to a Unibroue on draft or in the small bottles not given enough chance to do its thing. The aroma has subdued fruit, lychee pear pineapple almost smells like Unibroue with some ripe mashed banana with coriander, mashed fruit salad, and the wood adds astringency to the palate more than it adds to the flavors. Apples and peaches, deskinned, fruit salad. The palate is soft like velour, almost too soft. A livelier, pricklier carbonation wouldnt hurt and might lift it a bit. Does have great fruit character. Mostly unripe/green carambola. Acidity that is subdued but just enough to affect the palate more so than the flavors. Lots of unripe random subtropical tree fruit. Some tart apples and white grapes. Hardly any tannins in the finish, I would want more. You have to really search for the wood and when it is found, it manifests as a kiss of vanilla tobacco sweets. Which is kinda strange. This is a subtle and understated beer and if it werent a RR I might rate it higher, which is kind of silly but its just not wowyzawy. Of course its still very good.

Pours a translucent gold color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is long on the Belgian yeast, spicy, a little fruity. This is the single most drinkable Belgian-style I have ever had the privilege of drinking. Taste is grassy, spicy, with a potent kick turning into an incredibly smooth finish. Very well crafted.
Thanks to whomever brought this bad-boy.  Wasnt as shock-and-awed as I was expecting.  That said, a nice sipper with strong oak.
375 ml. Bottle pour.  Golden color with a thick white head.  Belgian yeast in the aroma with hints of oak.  The taste is what the aroma advertises.  Nice surprise.

375ml bottle from El Cerrito).  Pours a clear golden color with massive chunky white head and active carbonation.  Some nice lacing is left behind.  Aroma is belgian yeast, lemon, pepper, and some wood.  Taste is sweet with some light bitterness and a bit of spiciness.  Medium bodied with a slick texture.  Finish shows the alcohol and is warming.  A bit harsh.  Pretty good, but a bit rough around the edges.

Bottle from a trade, generously provided by hamilton23.  Cheers, Steve!  Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a foamy white head that recedes. Nose is big oak and oaky vanilla followed quickly by light malt, slight apple, and oh, hello more oak.  Flavor is similar with oak coming to the forefront quickly and pushing the sweet malts and hints of funk away.  Light to medium in body and good, just not what I expected from a Damnation.
Hazy yellow pour with bubbly white head. Aroma is spicy and fruity Belgian esters. Taste is also fruity with nice balance.

Bottle, couresty khuiljoebee. Pours blonde with a massive white head, excellent retention/lacing. Aroma of fruity esters, light oak, floral hops, bread. Taste is really nice fruitiness with banana, orange, vanilla, bread, very light oak, light sweetness. Palate is dry, soft, average carbonation, clean finish. Overall very good.

Bottle thanks to Shane! Pours a hazy gold with a white head that dissipates quickly and completely. Aroma has notes of light fruit and flora with a nice oak note and a hint of funk. Flavor has a good amOunt of light fruits with backing flora and sweet grains with a hint of oak.

Boy O Boy! Onto something here, mmm HM!! I let this warm up some out of the fridge to about perfect temp. Poured with a colossal, foamy, frothy, fluffy, sudsy, off-white head that soon settles down to some scud  and some lace. Color is a clear amber with bubble trails. Aroma is yeast, hop, malt, oak, caramel, spice, bread dough and makes me want to quit screwing around and DRINK IT!!! Flavor doesnt let me down a bit - very similar to nose, but all have more impact, vineous, and flat out tasty. Very true to style. Body and carbonation is similarly true to style. Finish is like flavor and trends more towards vineous and has the slap happy boozieness. Wot a beer. Yessir.

Appearance: Pours out a cloudy, hazed orange with a frothy, white head.

Smell: Aroma of an oaken banana boat crossing your lake-going path, notes of sweet-scented, bready pale malted barley, phenolic spiciness, orchard fruits, and with a fleeting hint of lavender on the nose.

Taste: Moderately sweet in the fore with a taste of bready, candyish, honey-glazed pilsner malts. Small, quick dash of 99 Bananas for bit of sting over sliced pears and gala apples. Slight citrus. Very minute hop bitterness. Spicy, butter American oak character late and into the semi-dry, persistently fruity finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Theres an ever so slight, tongue-coating creaminess to the mouthfeel.

Overall: A solid, oak-aged tripel. Yes, thats what we call it.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 Batch 69.  Been wanting to try this one for a while now.  Bottle from Beverages4less.  This pours a hazy orange color with a nice fluffy white head that dies down to a relatively thin lasting layer.  The aroma right away shows banana, pear, and citrus.  Its not until after a few whiffs do I get a strong oak character.  This really just tastes like a good strong Triple with sharp citrus, orange, banana, oak, sweet malt, a little alcohol sting, and some farmhouse character that kind of gets buried underneath the sharper flavors.  Good beer, although probably not as memorable or complex as I thought it might be.  Im glad to have finally gotten the chance to try this beer but I cant say the oak and added abv has made Damnation a better beer.
10 nov 2011, bottle. Batch 23. Tan/lemon, slightly hazy. Smells like a Belgian farmhouse. Soft lemon rind and straw. Med/thin and almost flat. Slightly sweet farmyard ale. Nice and refreshing.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy amber gold with a thin creamy cap atop.

Aroma: Vanilla, wood and banana.

Taste: Vanilla and  banana right off the bat. Cantaloupe, oak, custard.

Mouthfeel. Avery prickly bubbles. Thick mouthfeel.

Overall:  I love this beer after some time on oak.

On tap at Russian River Brewing Company. I found this beer to be very, very similar to the base beer. It didnt have as much complexity added as I had hoped for. That being said It didnt need much to make it an even better beer. I still found a fruity note that came through. I dont know whether that is the yeast or an ingredient but it helps to balance the beer.

Bottle.  Cloudy golden pour with plenty of head and some fabulous lacing.  Visually a great beer.  Nose is similar to the regular version but with some grape like notes and less by way of fruitiness.  Taste is a little of a miss for me compared to the regular batch.  Some alcohol bitterness and tart sourness u was not expecting.  I am getting none of the oak chips and am left to wonder if "two-three weeks" of aging is oxymoronic?  A bit too much carbonation but still a good beer.

Pours a clear golden yellow with a frothy white head.  Aroma is oak and layers of sweet, complex malt and an herbal hop component.  Taste is light candied sugar, soft sweet malt, subtle honey, llight dates, a bit of alcohol bitterness, and soft hops.  Exceptionally well balanced beer.  Excellent.

Huge thanks to TurdFurgison, who decided to destroy quite a few of my wants last night. Served in a Bruery tulip.

Pours a slightly-cloudy golden color with a large off-white head with good retention and nice lacing. The nose brings forward a bit of bready malt and then carries through with some oak. Beyond that, theres a good amount of yeast coming through with nice notes of banana, bubble gum, and some clove. Medium body. Light dryness from the oak. Light booze in the finish as well. Really nice beer that I was thrilled to finally try. Thanks again, Eric.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-13-2011

Batch 23 bottle. Bright golden pour, huge head . Aromas of oak, peach, apricot, bourbon, butter, pear. Wow. Beautiful depth of flavor with amazing balance. Oak, vanilla, peach, apricot, bourbon, berries, black pepper. Just unbelievable. Smooth, full palate. So close to perfect.

bottle batch 23 big thanks to secret santa! pour has a honey golden color with a covering of white head. aroma has vanilla, oak, nice base golden ale, yeast, and a bit of hops remaining.  mouth feel is medium and there is low side carbonation. flavor has a lot of barrel character with a big vanilla dose. the base golden ale holds up well, somewhat spicey yeast, a flowery poke, apricot, and a little bit of sweetness. for a beer brewed almost four years ago acording to the russian river bottle log this has done very well for a barrel aged golden beer.

The ber pours a dark honey gold with a hint of orange. The white rises about 3 fingers providing great retention and lacing. 

The aroma is pretty light but very sweet to start, maybe butterscotch, some clove? As you dig in more you get some nice floral of a tripel with a hint of oak at the end. Very nice, balanced and complex. 

The taste is also very balanced and complex. It starts our a little sweet and light fades to some nice floral hoppiness then ends with some great oak and as you swallow a great hint of vanilla.

The feel is light, warm with a semi dry finish.

This beer is very drinkable.

Overall, this is a great beer. It retains all the qualities that make a great triple but then ads a great uniqueness with the oak.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured a cloudy orange with a white head.  Big oaky nose.  Nice spirit-like quality.  Malts and still some nice earthy hop qualities from the Batch 23.  Yeasty finish and lots of candied-like sweetness.

Batch 23 - Smallish white head. Body is cloudy and orangy-peachy colored. Slight aroma of apricots. Initial flavor is of peach with alcohol quickly catching up to it. Definitely more rounded than the standard Damnation.

A: The pour is a cloudy orange color with a fluffy and somewhat soapy white head. A bit of white head.

S: Some slightly tart fruits like apples and lemons, maybe a bit of grapes as well. Some nice oak aromas, sweet bready malts, honey, and some undertones of alcohol.

T: Lots of great fruit flavors along with a bit of warming alcohol. Sweet apples, pears, and some citrus zest. Honey, and some floral notes to it, and maybe a slight spice ester character. Nowhere near as much as the usual Damnation.

M: The body is medium with a moderate to high carbonation and a slightly drying.

D: Very different from regular Damnation, and probably for the best. I really enjoyed this beer. Would love to have it again.

Bottle. Batch 46, courtesy of mothman. Pours a deeper hazed amber orange color than the regular Damnation. The head is a tiny bubbled small head of an offwhite color. Very good retention and lacing as it settles. The nose is more subdued than the regular version as well but it has notes of citrus, pineapple, pear, and oak. Some booze notes as well. Light/medium mouthfeel with good carbonation. The flavor to me is very strong apricot with mixes of oak. Nice hop notes as well. Ends dryly.

Pours a pale golden orange, nose is weak. Mostly yeast esters and light stone fruit, hint of eRthiness. Taste is a tad chalky, mild sweetness, tannic, but no vanilla oak qualities. Pretty disappointing, but still good.
Batch 46 tasted on tap at Toronado. Golden hues in the glass. Good smooth mouthfeel with sweet malt. bready flavors. Alcohol and oaky taste are quite apparent.  Pretty good beer.

Batch 46.  Im not really a fan of tripels, but I am very Bullish on this Jordan tribute.  The bottle poured a semi-hazy golden orange color with a nice frothy white head.  The nose is a sweet and spicy finger roll.  The taste is a shake and bake rise up mid-range jumper with light fruit and spices.  I love the regular Damnation, but like The Answer, this up and comer deserves all the street cred it has garnered.......

Batch 046, tasted from a 750mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours hazy orange with a thick and frothy white head that leaves thick lace behind.  The nose is sweet with vanilla and cinnamon oak, red apple, caramel malt, and both light yeast and hops.  There is something very vinous about this.  The flavor really features the oak, but the fruity apple and grape flavors are also very prevalent.  It is brown sugar sweet, but not cloyingly so, with the yeast, hops, and caramel malt all providing just the right amount of flavor.  The body is medium plus with a sticky texture, average carbonation, and a long vanilla, brown sugar, and fruit finish.

Batch 23 sampled 10/28/10. 

Pours a deep rich maize with a modest head. Vanilla oak is very forward on the aroma, mild esters. The flavor is surprisingly sweet but it works, an oaked tripel that for all the world recalls a rich belgian-yeasted barleywine. Honey and peaches with more vanilla. Alcohol is subdued after however many years its been. I came to this one with expectations along below the beers general reputation (why? I guess because Im not a big fan of the ordinary Damnation) but it lived up to its reputation and then some. Great beer.

Draft at Toronado.  A hazy orange with a small white head that leaves a small amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is belgian yeast, oak, and a bit of alcohol.  Taste is of sweet oak and belgian yeast.  A bit of grapes as well with the alcohol coming through a bit on the finish.  Light bodied.  Great beer.

Batch 46.  Bottle crushed with CaryTheDude. Pours hazy orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of earth, light fruit, oak.  Slight alcohol burn on the nose.  Flavor is dry, light fruit, earth, oak.  Really nice.  Well- carbonation.  Really awesome brew.

Thanks to cloudskipper.  This review is a long time coming since I aged this brew for over a year.  Crushed with Honkeybra.  Complex and original.  Very fruity with the oak and a touch of alcohol adding a nice dryness to the finish.  An unusual tripel.  Still dont like tripels, but this one is nice.

tasting on 7/30/10.  deep golden pour with 1/4" white head - sure this would have more in a bigger pour.  nice oak nose with some Belgian yeast notes.  medium body with deep fruits, apple, citrus and sugar.  very smooth body.  citrus / oak finish.  glad I got to try this one!

Bottle courtesy of BeerandBlues2, shared at Winter gathering on 1/10/10.  Color is a hazy yellow with fair carbonation and a thin head.  Aroma of orange.  This medium bodied brew has a crisp mouth feel with flavors of orange, vanilla and oak.  After taste is a mildly bitter.  Overall this is a very tasty brew, well done.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, batch #46 courtesy of zminor on BA. thanks, zac! pours a hazy, yellow-gold with a full, fizzy, white head leacing a lasting collar of lace. aroma is wonderful with soft, slightly tart fruit notes of lemon zest, orange, apricot, and white grape backed by banana, clove, and spicy belgian yeast all draped in slightly sweet oak, vanilla, and cedar. flavor is wonderful as well with notes of hay, light brett funk, and floral hops joining the citrus and white wine fruit notes with hints of pear and pineapple backed by dry, chalky, oak, vanilla creme, and spicy belgian yeast. as is warmed, this one really became similar to a fruity carrot cake and im digging the slight funk/tartness. palate is medium bodied and creamy on the palate with refreshing, fizzy carbonation and a dry, fruity, oaked finish. overall, another winner from russian river.

750ml (batch 46) caged and corked bottle.

Appearance: A touch more amber/dirty than the normal Damnation blond. 2 finger white crown that rapidly dissipates but shows some lace.

Smell: Loads of banana and bubblegum phenols along with a touch of oak, spice, and alcohol.

Taste: Loads of alcohol soaked oak chips in the flavor along with a nice belgian tripel meets bavarian hefe flavor profile.

Mouthfeel: Exceptionally well done for a brew with an abv about ten. Creamy, medium bodied and a touch chewy.

Drinkability: The abv holds this one back but not the flavor profile!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-29-2009

Got this in a trade awhile Damnation 23 (46)!

A-Bottle makes a HUGE champagne popping sound when cork is removed. Body is a crystal clear pale amber hue. Pours with a 1 finger white fizzy head that fades to a thick collar pretty quickly and little to no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is quite interesting. It contains dry, dusty oak, a hint of acidic tartness, vinegar, a slight sugary sweetness, some funky yeast, and a hint of apple.

T- Flavor contains a hint of smoke initially and dry woody oak. Background contains a good amount of spicy belgian yeast. The finish is actually very spicy with the spicy yeast increasing and what seems to be a ginger hotness. A moderate amount of spicy heat lingers on for awhile.

P- Light body with soft carbonation. Relatively smooth and yeasty.

Russian River Damnation Batch 46

Thanks to bman1113vr for sharing this California gem.

The beer pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a white head. The aroma is citrus (both lemon and orange) with some oaked character. The flavor is orange, oak, lemon and a nice dose of vanilla. The alcohol is very well hidden and unless you look at the label, you would have no idea this beer was 11 percent. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

750mL bottle courtesy of MakeItaBanquet poured into a tulip.

Pours bright golden orange with the slightest haze and a huge creamy white head that recedes to a thick cap and some delicate lacing.

The aroma is really nice and very sweet with caramelized green apples and apricots alongside some more citrusy pineapples.  Hints of spicy yeast with vanilla and oak as well.

The taste is also sweet with apples, pears and candi sugar.  But, it does seem a little spicier than the aroma with the Belgian yeast coming out as well as a heavier dose of the oak character, wood and vanilla in the finish.

The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation and pretty stick and less dry than many tripels.

I love this beer and its ridiculous that an 11% ABV beer is this drinkable.  Sweeter than most tripels but balanced by the oak - a wonderful beer.

In short: An interesting vanilla cake ale with vanilla and a little wild touch.  Really nice
How: Bottle 750ml.  Batch #2 of this oak age beer (batch 46 of Damnation).  Consumed when about 1 year of age.  Sent to me by MakeItaBanquet, thanks a lot Ben for this rare treat.
The look: Partly cloudy dark blonde body topped by a small white head
In long: Nose of vanilla ice-cream, certainly the closest thing to vanilla ice-cream I ever got from a beer aroma.  Taste is sweet bananas, pineapple cake (renversé aux ananas in quebec), vanilla extract, a little wild yeast.  Alcohol very well hidden.  I didnt pick up any oak/wood in this all, just a lot of vanilla.  I can recognize the regular Damnation in there. It is sweeter than the regular Damnation, less nilla bretty and less dry that the regular.  However vanilla other additions are quite nice.  At the end its an equal match, I like the regular as much as this special oak aged version.  Both versions are very good, almost excellent.  Im glad I got the opportunity to drink a bottle of this Damnation 0.5 (Oak Aged)
Pours a deep cheddar with a nose of pilsner malt.  Light, yeasty raisin and plumb flavors tickle the tongue.  Thick and coating mouthfeel.  Perty good.

text: I definitely prefer this to the original Damnation just for the subtle bits that make it more complex... Hazy Golden, big belgian golden ale with faint notes of oak and vanilla, not entirely different than the original but with the oak and the addition of more aggressive hopping..

Batch 46. Pours orange with a small, off-white head. Aroma is of citrus, oak, funk, vanilla, and yeast. Taste is very oaky to start. There is also lots of citrus, dark fruit, and vanilla. Has a very funky fruit taste ot it, almost like a dry wine. It doesnt really have any Belgian characteristics until it warms, when some spice, yeast, and banana start to come through. Lingering taste of oak and sour fruit. Very easy drinking. Very light carbonation. Any alcohol is well hidden.
Batch 46.  Just superb subtle oak notes of vanilla integrated seamlessly into an already stellar beer.  Mouthfilling body and flavors or tropical fruit and flowers.  Excellent.

75cl bottle cracked on my 23rd birthday, batch 46.   Clear amber color with a thick white head displaying very tight bubbles and lace.   Oak is the dominant first impression in the aroma, with some spices reminiscent of cloves and cinnamon.   There is a touch of carrot cake sweetness and honey, some flowers, and a touch of lemon tang.   The flavor starts with a definite candy sweetness.   Moderate oak spice and tannin.   The oak profile is not unlike some red wines actually.   Strong vanilla.   The finish dries out pretty well, with the oak and alcohol working with a medium-mild bitterness against the initial sweetness.   Medium bodied with a touch of alcohol heat and nice, tight carbonation.   The oak is more dominant than I had anticipated, and is the main balance against the candied pils malt sweetness, as the hops are pretty mellow at this point.   You have to be in the mod for some oak, but this is really cool and well put together stuff.

Bottle batch 046: Pours a hazy effervescent golden with a dense white head that retains throughout. Dry, fruity aroma with a mild vanilla oak presence. Some chalky Belgian dry phenols, dry doughy yeast, orange, sweet oak, and prunes. Complex aroma. Fluffy light body with a softly sweet flavor. The Belgian malts dry out leading to chalky phenols. Some sweet ciruses are present as well with mild vanilla from the oak. All the sweet notes are very soft and subtle with some peppery vegetal notes on the back. Dries out nicely. A nice U.S. version of a Belgian Tripel.

750 ml from way back courtesy of cloudskipper. Batch 46. Thanks! Pours a hazy golden orange, summer dusk sun with a huge offwhite leaning towards beige cakey head, very well carbonated and lively. Aromas are the telltale fruity ester base of Damnation, citrus and banana come into focus, a slight apple with light yeasty Belgian character, not overdone or overspiced, instead playing to the fruit side of things with a touch of buttery oak underneath, a touch of wet wood and slight vanilla mellow feel. Initial is fuller, lighter side of medium bodied with a lively carbonation and a fairly prominent alcohol base. Fruity banana, pear, apple, spicey Belgian yeast, a grainy malt base moving into a sweeter spiced ale. The beer is served well by the oak chips, with some wet oak, a touch of butter, vanilla coming and playing on. A bit more muted in sweetness as we get in after the initial shock, this beer becomes surprisingly smooth, light sweetness and smoothed out oak to round the edges. The beer laces very the well, the head staying huge throughout. I love how a lot of the spicy yeast starts to die out, the oak playing a more prominent role of taming the spice and sweetness, making a smooth and becoming easily quaffable beer. A finish that becomes a bit drier, the hops coming to life, the elements still sticking to the palate, sweet and oaky, light spice, smoothed out, dry finish from decent hop profile. How will I ever finis this by myself? ...well, Ill have to manage. ;) Cheers, all.

750ml, batch 46.  The pour yields a cloudy, glowing, golden orange-amber body.  A small, foamy, cream colored blanket sits at the head, its frothy edge leading into drippy, soapy lines of lace. 
The aroma kicks off with a fresh, bready, doughy, caramelized sugar malt base, showing notes of creamy lemon chiffon.  New American oak imparts ample vanilla, along with a good amount of woody spice.  The flavor is rich with honeyed, fresh grain malt, hinting at honey wheat bread dipped in cream.  Oak again offers up vanilla and lightly toasted spice, while a smattering of floral hops lends just a hint of countering bitterness.  The finish is quite oaky.  Medium-plus in hefty and viscosity, the palate sports a rich, creamy, lightly carbonated mouthfeel that shows little in the way of alcoholic heat.  Very nice brew.  I think it may be a touch more subdued that the non-oaked version.
[Batch 23] Yeast, vanilla, some oak, and a bit of sweet in the aroma. Has a really nice carbonation. Some spice, clove, banana, some oak. Much more flavourful than the original.

750mL Bottle. Thanks Andy! Olfactories are lit with a murky herbal quality, a bit of licorice and mint. Musky. Colored a golden-orange, with a settled even white. Flavors brighten quickly and give off mercurial sweet sugars in line with lemoncello, white wine, and almond paste. Sugars are immediately chewy and the alcohols prickle the tongue. Im having trouble digging depth out of this beer, though. Theres a run of oak dryness, some curt vanillic acids, and a bit of northern Indian spice mixture. Dryed out and slightly past-peak hop leafiness bring up the backend. Solid brewing and a decent beer, but maybe not as wildly successful an effort as Id hoped. I usually hate American oak in beer, so I see it as good work that I dont dislike this beer.
Hazy golden pour.  White head.  Aroma of yeast, fruit, wood and some light floral hops.  Flavor is a bit sweet and yeasty with some nice oak hints.  Really nice.
Bottle.  Dark gold pour, almost brown.  Off-white head.  Sweet malt, dried fruit, noticable oak notes, and sweet bread.  Nice beer, I enjoyed it and was glad to try.
