Pours golden orange with great big bubbles and a fantastic head with sticky lacing. Flavors are initially somewhat sweet pear, green apples, dusty notes, a nice citrus bitterness, spicy yeast notes, and a subtle dryness from the oak chips that really works well to round this one out. Nice bubbly mouth feel, seemed richer and fuller to me than many other tripels. Had no clue this was 11%, that would probably explain why I was a little drunk afterwards. Would not have been able to tell at all.

batch 23 bottle shared by cbkschubert...
cloudy yellow-orange shade of brown with a small white ring of a head. 

theres an odd bubblegum aroma that initially jumps out at me... followed by fresh oranges, citrus blossoms, pale grain, yeast and a bit of woody spice. 

i dreaded sipping this for fear of it being too sweet (bastard sweet tripels!) but was pleasantly surprised... especially given the abv% and how it is not masked with sugar yet well hidden. flavors of ripe danjou pear, clove, cinnamon, pale maltiness, warming yeast and vanilla with a dry almost herbaceous finish. 

medium to full body has some substance and richness from the yeast(?).8/4/8/4/18/4.2

Bottle shipped from Ryan just in time to share with the Carolina Crew.  This was the beer of the night for me, possibly due in part to its lighter flavors in contrast to the big impy stouts and barleywines.  Hazy deep golden pour with foamy white head.  Peppery, fruity, and yeasty.  Nice citrus notes and the oak was really subtle.  Not overdone at all.  Nice dry finish.  Damn good.
Bottle from Monument in Concord, CA.  This beer tasted a lot like La Fin Du Monde by Unibroue, although I felt it had a little bit more alcohol burn.  Full, dry, and tasty...  Great beer!
UPDATED: APR 13, 2009 Every time I have this I like it more and more. A nice tart and sour taste and a nice citrus and tart aroma. Nice and dry, awesome.

Bottle of batch 23 shared at the Smoke from the Oak release. Pours a hazy gold with a thin white head. Nice lemon and citrus aromas with a nice soft malty wheat back to it.  Thick bodied and sweet with honey, citrus, sweet fruit, and malt notes.  Tangy crisp finish.  I was very happy to have gotten to sample this one, and it lived up to my expectations quite well.

First pour was dregs from a shared beer...all yeast. Had to get a some from another glass.  Still very cloudy and bright gold. It still has all the tropical flavors that I expect from a tripel and it is rather mellow but not very woody. Still very solid.

Huge thanks to durhambeer for sharing this beauty - rock on, Bob! I heart regular Damnation, and I had long wondered if this experiment would complement or undermine the great beer. Definitely the former! As a tripel, it retains its sharp and yeasty qualities. There are more sweet flavors in there for sure, at times even slightly intense, leading to a somewhat boozy finish. But somehow that works, especially when combined with the oak and spice presence. Nice!

Thanks to bob for sharing this one.  Cloudy bright gold pour with a fluffy white head and spotty lace.  Lemon, yeast,  and spice.  Medium bodied with notable hints citrus, candi sugar and light alcohol.  Oak was not as prominent as I hoped, but still a solid offering

Thanks durhambeer for sharing. Pours a hazy honey gold with a one finger offwhite head. The nose is yeasty, peppery, fruity, oaky, mildly tannic. Flavor is yeasty, peppery, nice and spicy, citrusy, mild bitterness, oaky tannic feel. Prefer the original to this. Still nice though. Not much oak comes through though.

On tap at the brewery. This golden ale poured with a fluffy white head and a candy aroma. There is a sweet caramel malt flavor and some nice effects from the yeast. The hopping balanced the sweetness, creating a quite delicious mouthful. Yet another great beer from this brewer.

Bottle.  Pours hazy golden amber with a decent white head.  Nose is candy sugar, spicy yeast, and oak.  Taste is similar, but with more caramel and a little tobacco.  The oak wasnt as big as I had hoped.  Mouthfeel is nice; finish is bitter and slightly smoky.
FRO throwdown: Light wheat and hay, some barn loft. Theres a touch of orange and clove. Herbal. I didnt like this much. Maybe its because Im liking the clove phenol less and less.

Sample at O-town throwdown 09
courtesy of fogdog.
pours hazy golden.
Taste of some dark fruits, malty  banana, peach, apricot.
Belgian yeast presence, with light and pleasant wood oak palate.
Solid brew.

On tap at OBriens Russian River night. Pours a clear dark gold with a white ring. Sweet aroma, of malt, sugar, and dark fruits. Taste is rich and sweet, a bit herbal, with malt, brown sugar, dark fruits, and wood. Lingering rich sweetness. Very tasty.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Pours hazy amber orange, malty, honey, fruity, caramel, little citrus, little wood slight vanilla, slight spice.

Sampled at hellbillys hellraiser 3 gathering.  Bottle courtesy of cbkschubert.  Pours a hazy apricot color with a ring of head.  Malt, sugar, yeast, light fruit and wood in the aroma and flavor.  A good solid brew.  Thanks Craig!

Bottle.  A rich golden color with a big foamy white head.  The aroma has definite oak chips (wood) on the otherwise nice Belgian tripel base (lemon, banana and cloves).  Dry, candy sugars, spiced, and light fruits in the flavor.
On tap at brewery. This beer was damn good. Like the regular damnation but strong oak and a still surprisingly hoppy taste.

Bottle from OBriens: Created a firm layer of fluffy head which eventually retreated into an O shaped ring. Dense color of golden liquid with a slight murky appearance. Aroma detected was a strong strain of Belgian yeast and spices which ultimately satisfied the nose. Flavor was strong with the usual suspects accompanied with Belgian yeast but an ever present background of wood chips, tart cherries and perhaps a chardonnay wine finished with an interesting taste compared to the original version.

Bottle @ OBriens.  Poured hazy gold with a thick, foamy white head.  Some lacing on the goblet.  Lovely sweet French oak barrel, Belgian yeast, cloves, and lots of lighter fruits (apples, grapes, peaches).  Effervescent mouthfeel, very light.  Compliments the flavor nicely.  Sweet peaches and white grapes up front, even sweeter yeast and malt.  Nive vanilla/clove spice combo, close to what you may find in a trippel.  The oak gives this a flavor far different than the usual Damnation.  It is still sweet, but the slight earthiness keeps this from being sickening.  Dry finish.  Great beer.

Bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy blond with a thin head. Belgian yeast  and cookie dough nose. What happens when  you take a great beer and age it with oak chips, it just gets that much better. This is a really nice belgian style triple that has depth,complexity, and is delicious. The malt base of the Russian River beers just really works for my palate. Nice dried fruit flavors and some spice make this a beer to rival those from across the pond.

Aroma is very light clove, with esters and fruits in there. Pours an amber, just a little darker than Damnation. Flavor is sweet, with notes of clove, peppercorns and some tannins.  Doughy flavors, as well as sugar highlight this beer. Ends on a sweet note. Shit they should make this ALL the time!

From bottle (at bottling facility gatherhing). Pours bronze, slight hazy,with subtle aroma of dough and mineral. Flavor of dense syurp and crystal malty goodness with some oak matched by medium body and a longer finish. Bold and crisp for a tripel.

My first beer of the night last time I was at the T Room.  Tap.  Smells and tastes harder than any Tripel ever should.  I call this a Belgian Strong, for sure.  The wood is totally hidden for me, only imparting the color of the barrel - if that makes any sense.  Really petrified fruit (barely), bitter hops and the suggestion of yeast.  Kinda heavy.  Kind of a chore...

Courtesy of cbkschubert @ Hellbillys Hellraiser 3.0...THANKS CRAIG!!!  Hazy yellow pour; 14 karat with a soft eggshell head.  Aroma is peppery, Belgian yeast, and raw wood.  Flavor is oak, cedar, and pine...definitely barrel-forward along with spice and biscuit.  A little banana, natural sugars, and vanilla.  Pretty solid.

Bottle of the new one.  Nice deep orange pour with small white head.  Aroma is sweet banana / bubblegum, some sugar, apricot and syrup.  Flavor is the same, dense and fruity, and only some light wet wood flavor underneath and in the finish.  Good amount of spice in the finish as well.

On tap at the brewpub. Vibrant golden pour with a pencil thin white head. Very fruity aroma, much candi sugar as well. Sugared flavor with some apples and a yeasty feel and some spiciness. The oak does not really come through at all, but neither does the alcohol. A pleasant beer but I honestly enjoyed the 22 more.
Pours out hazy gold with creamy white head.  Taste is sweet malt with crisp hops. Not much oak flavor however nice spice and funk. Smooth and balanced. No alcohol burn. Great brew.

On tap @ the brewpub. Pours clear deep gold with micro thin white head. The aroma is full of apricot, sweet ripe apples, prunes, Belgian candi sugar and tart aspirin. The taste hits first with a wave of Belgian candi sugar to go along with thick sugary notes of apples, prunes and near ripe apricots. It then moves toward sugary malts before a dryness runs the experience to the finish. Very tasty stuff.

Draught at City Beers, SF
Golden with a medium, white head.
Spicy aroma with some grassiness.
Citrus and medium grassy bitterness in the flavour.
A very good tripel indeed!

Bottle of Batch 23 shared by cbkschubert at hellbillys hellraiser 3.0 tasting. Spice and wheat for aroma. Gold body with white head. Dry fermentation of spice, yeast and wheat. Medium bittering to brew on palate. Thanks Craig.

Bottle courtesy of cbkschubert at hellbillys house of horrors. Pours a hazy golden brownish color with a small white head. Aroma is yeasts, candi sugar, wood and malt. Flavor is candi sugar, belgian yeasts with some cinnamon, cloves, spices and coriander. Nice brew.

Bottle of Batch 23 shared by cbkschubert at hellbillys hellraiser 3.0 tasting.  Pours a murky gold with a small off-white head.  The nose is Belgian sugar, spice and oaky vanilla.  The taste is sweet malt, light banana, ripe fruits and spicy Belgian yeast.  Medium bodied.  Good stuff - thanks Craig!

On tap at Russian River.  A phenomenal example of the style, maybe the best in the "Dam nation."  Nice golden yellow appearance with a white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, and light fruits.  Flavor is more sweet malt and yeast, citrus fruits, pear, apple, and oak.  Medium-full mouthfeel for the style, alcohol incredibly well hidden.

Nose of malt, vanilla, pear, light citrus and oak.  Light gold to yellow in color, medium to thick mouthfeel.  Sweet malts, honey, toast, biscuit, vanilla, oak and light pear esters.   Medium finish, slightly sweet, low bitterness.  Interesting take, maybe a bit drier and more oak, still slight cloying nature to it.

Great head and lacing, had twice the head of normal damnation.  The sweetness is much more pronounced than the regular damnation (had them side by side).  Some wood character comes through, this is a much fuller beer.  The yeast does not fit perfectly with this style like it does with the normal batch.  This is an amazing transformation that shines on its own right, but keeps its similarities to the original.

Bottle. Batch 23 courtesy of Vinnie and shared with Vinnie @ Russian River. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a sweetish malty yeasty spicy aroma with some hints of oak and some hints of hops. Sweetish warming malty spicy and slightly yeasty flavor with some hints of oak. Has a warming malty spicy yeasty finish.

Unreal. Wonderful golden, hazy wiht a white head. Just amazing aroma of marzipan, meringue, and faint, faint, clove. The oak is deftly balanced. The alcohol imperceptible.... other than the fact that you achieve the Perfect Buzz after a pint... bartender ! Give me another one.

2006 vintage. In the bottle thanks to bditty187. Pours rich hazy gold with a thin white head. Gooseberry meringue pie aroma. Like an egg cream and ramon fizz. At first, it has lemon verbena flavors. High alcohol and fairly dry for such a big beer. Does this have honey in it? It is so dry that it seems like it is a mead that has been finished with Pasteur yeast. Cloying almonds and a splash of lemon. Im not sure that I understand this beer.

On draft at OBriens. Aroma of yeast, spices, sweet malts, and oak. Flavor is solid Tripel style with accents by the oak chips and boosted hop levels, very thick and solid on flavor. A great variation on the standard Damnation, would like to try again with some aging.

Draft at OBriens Russian River night.  Pours a mostly clear medium gold color with a small off white ring.  Nose was sweet and fruity with hints of oak and vanilla.  Flavor was quite sweet as well with some wood present as well as candied tree fruits.  Another great one from Russian River.

Tap at OBriens 15th annv.  If I could get this damnation all the time I would.  Oak gives that added texture, a little vanilla and superb body and length.  Really a stand out beer for me.  Vinnie noted it was batch 46, I guess it seeks oak every 23 batches.  Would love to see this with 1 or 2 years of age.  This was from Keg and outstanding.

Shared bomber behind Ihop from Devin.  This is awesome to compare with the regular damnation.  Damnation has to be in my top five favorite beers.  The tasgte is a little more sour compared to the regular but is equally as smooth.

7/28/2007: Damnation 23 pours a hazy golden orange color. It has a lasting, foamy white head. The aroma is somewhat yeasty and the flavor is lightly sweet and malty. There are notes of light vanilla and wood (like oak chips). The alcohol is extremely well hidden. This is a great beer that needs to be tried again in another environment so that it can be fully enjoyed and respected. Sample from 750 mL bottle (11.00% Alc. by Vol.) shared at the "Columbus Tasting: Ate, now with gramatical errors" event. Thanks! Rating #110 for this beer...

25.4 oz bottle.  Clearish pale orange with a thin white haze.  Nose is yeasty honey and sage.  Surprisingly full body with prickly carb.  Taste, like the nose, is honey and herbal with vanilla and alcohol.  Though not overly sweet this still feels a bit cloying.  Dry finish, kind of chalky with citrus peel.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2008 Bottle. in a trade.  Orange yellow body 2 finger head.  Oak, woodiness, light sweet malt character.  A dry finish. Sour apples, some noticable etoh.  Spices, pepper, edit big etoh in the finish.   I loved it.
After having this a second time i have to drop it from a 4.1 the spoiled fruit flavors i kept getting made this less enjoyable.

Bottle shared with Blankboy, Jerc, Garthicus, GregClow, and Hogotwn Harry, courtesy of Harry.  Oaky aroma, vanilla, alcohol.  Hazy yellow, foamy white head.  Good taste, very oaky, strong.  A little too much oak.  Good though.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev, jerc & garthicus - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Slightly hazy dark gold with a tiny white head. Aroma of caramel, orange, herbal hops, and a good dose of oak. Medium bodied. Flavour is very oaky with a pleasant sweetness, some caramel malt and dark sugar, nicely hopped finish, and a very balanced flavour for an 11%er. It’s nice to have a wood-aged beer that uses new chips rather than bourbon or wine barrels - while those obviously work nicely for some beers, they can often be very overpowering, but this beer strikes a great balance. Well done!

Started in on this when eating a Porterhouse steak simmered with various spices and worchestershire sauce. It tasted odd to me then but as I made short work of the steak and move to cheese slices with rosemary crackers, it was like drinking a different beer. Initially, I thought it rough and a bit like a young Cabernet, brash & tannic, I wasn’t impressed. A combination of the beer warming, and my palate switching gears as I moved from the steak into cheese both melded this into a sweet, rich tripel. It is still a bit bold (American oak, I wonder how it would have been if aged in French Oak?) I enjoyed the herbal hops at the finish. Damn I miss having access to decent beer!

Shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, Tupalev,Jerc & Blankboy -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Appearance: Beautiful orange body, slightly cloudy with a small off white head. Aroma - like a yeasty chardonnay. Flavour: Complex - slight alcohol, peppery, oaky, hickory, sweet! so much going on but wonderfully balanced!

Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, tupalev, jerc & garthicus -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy yellow-gold with a small diminishing fizzy white head. Aroma: Lots of oak (but not too much, its just right), fruit, funky yeast and herbal hops. Sweet flavour of oak, caramel malt, fruit, funky yeast, alcohol, candi sugar and hops. Dry bitter finish. Alcohols fairly well hidden for an 11% beer. Medium bodied. Barrel-aging done right -- a fantastic beer!

2008-08-15. Hazy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of wood tinged pale malts, light yeast and alcohol. (7+) Flavour is alcohol soaked pale malt, quite oaky. It is not over the top with the wood, but it is quite dominant. Subtle malt background cannot successfully compete with the lasting impression of oak. (6+) Average plus palate. Nice, but the core flavour is not one I love. Average plus palate.  Bottle shared by HogTownHarry

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, garthicus, GregClow and jerc via trade with Irishboy.  Hazy light orange-gold, decent fizzy-creamy white head.  Soft, sweet oaky aroma, sweet fruit medley aroma - the oak ageing is stunning on this.  Taste - softer even, wonderful lemon and ripe banana, the oak is even milder than in the aroma, and very muted alcohol for 11%.  Soft (again!) body, light acidity and carbonation, a little bitter in the finish.  Excellent!  Thanks, Richard!

Thanks to IrishBoy for sharing this bottle at the RBSG 08 Grand Tasting.  Poured into my La Chouffe goblet.  Pale gold in color with a white head.  The froth reduces to a halo, leaving sticky lace everywhere.  Aroma is oak-forward, with banana esters providing sweetness.  Flavor is very fruity, mostly banana with accents of tropical and stone fruits.  Boozy mid-palate with an earthy oaky finish.  Very smooth, classic RR mouthfeel.

Bottle at RBSG grand tasting, sketchy notes - I was surely getting drunk but someone VERY kind gave me some of this - thanks a lot :) Smooth aroma. Spiced and caramel also in the flavour and slight woody and spiced finish.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2009 At RBSG, subtle sweet fruit and spice nose along with the flavor. Very smooth and dangerous as there was no sign of alcohol. RERATE: New 46 version is sweeter with lots of honey and a decent amount of oak. Very nice!

~RBSG ’08~

Bottle at Grand Tasting. Pours a very cloudy mango color, with a very frothy white head, and thick ring of white lacing around the beer’s top. Ripe fruits in the nose, banana, and a slight tartness. Nice fruit flavors, banana, citrus, mango, and an empty malt backbone. Very good. Refreshing and crisp, smooth bodied. Love it.
Thanks to Rciesla for sharing.  Not a fan at all.  Really boozy in the nose and flavor.  Overwhelms the beer.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg! Pours cloudy dark gold with a thin white head. Sweet  aroma of brown sugar, citrus and vanilla. Sweet and creamy medium body. Taste of bread and citrus. Semi-dry spice and vanilla finish.

This Belgian Tripel pours a orange gold color from a corked 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head, with nice retention. The aroma is orange and floral, yeasty and a touch of brett. A medium bodied Belgian Tripel. The malts are fruity and sweet, with lots of orange, apricot and citrus. The hops are citrusy and floral. There is a slight touch of oak as well. Some spices, some brett and must. This beer is very hoppy for tripel, but is not overpowering and the spices, the hops and the oak blend well together. Lively carbonation. Hides the alcohol very well. This bottle has been sitting in the fridge for a year or so, wish I had a few more to age. Really nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and slightly dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
An old rating i finally got to entering. Aroma was of spices and belgian yeast. Flavor was sweet and had a light belgian yeastiness.  A little alcohol that comes through but not bad for 11%.
Sampled at Alesmith release on Friday the 13th. Thanks to who ever supplied this one. Spicy clove flavors up front with some oak in the finish. Very tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Bottle shared by miketd, thanks man.  Poured a murky yellow-orange color with a moderate off-white head that faded slowly.  Aroma of oak, yeast, sweet malt, and moderate citrus.  Flavor consists of some moderate sweet fruitiness (apple, apricot, light grapes) and yeast that fade into a lighty dry, oaky finish.  Nice oak character on the palate and smoother than regular Damnation.  Tasty stuff.

750ml body. Pours golden yellow with a thin, resilient white head, good lace, good retention. Smells sweet and citrusy, that could be the Belgian yeast flavor and the wood flavors mixing together. Tastes yeasty and bready with a sweet wood flavor towards the finish. Slight citrus flavors as well. Medium body, smooth, mellow carbonation as well.

5-24-08 bottle shared by Miketd - thanks! 
Semi cloudy thick yellow orange with an okay off white head that isnt big or too overwhelming.  Smell is quite light and mild and a hint grassy and woodsy.  Flavor is mild as well - it is oaky and has a good presence here.  Mouthfeel is nice.  Overall, another great one shared by Mike!

Just another rarity miketd generously shared with us during the tasting.  Thanks man!
Pours creamy and hazy gold.  Smell is bright, fresh malt with a touch of yeast.  Taste is sweet slightly lemony, belgian yeastiness and a noticeable oakiness at the end.  Pretty tasty stuff and I liked this better than regular Damnation for sure.
Huge thanks to after4ever. You rock. Wonderful mixture of citrus, green apple, mellow oak and a solid punch of alcohol. Booya. This was quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2009 750 ml bottle - huge thanks to annapolisbeer for this trade; pours a cloudy orange with foamy white head; beautiful haze throughout; nose is very sweet at first and a lovely mix of oak, musky malts and citrus fruits; texture is to die for as is flows down deep and smooth as can be; just amazing delicious on every level and i could easily drink this to my hearts content; thanks again kevin!!
Update 9/16/09 - had an aged bottle of the original batch 23; ugh = dont age!! became a syrupy, sweet mess and a shell of its former self

thank you irishboy!
a nice balanced oaky aroma mixed with the estery aromas that I love......great mouthfeel...though I would like a bit more carbonation.....good allaround beer...wish it was made instead of the normal damnnation!

I got a few generous hits of this whilst in line at DLD from the lovely <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1  Thanks, my friend.It poured a slightly hazed golden body with a slender fizzy head.  The aroma was yeasty, sweet pale malts, tart citrus fruit, mayhaps some pear, and a suggestion of oak.  Creamy.  It seems like a touch of funk and a bit of vanilla entered into the flavor, blending smoothly with sensations gathered from the nose.  Very nice indeed.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve Lord Day 2008 at Three Floyds, Munster, IN, 4/26/2008.<font size=-1>

25 oz bottle, shared by acrdz.  Pours a hazy gold body with a fizzy white head that retained very well.  Nice yeasty nose with airy doughy malt.  Flavor is pale doughy malt with a little bretty funkiness and a little oak, citrus fruit, and spiciness.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with fizzy prickly carbonation, on the drier side.  Overall, a slight improvement over the regular Damnation, a touch more complexity and depth.

750, corked and baled. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg! Crystal clear orangey light amber. Light gray fizz. Big orangey creamy nose. Rich medium fizzy body. Orangey, creamy, biscuity mid-palate. Very soft mineral tang. Just indescribably lovely in every way.
Bottle. An amped up Damnation with all the yeastiness of the regualr damnation and in addition a way stronger alcohol component and of course the oak. Keeps mellowing
Thanks to Mike for this.  Clear gold body.  Sweet honey aroma.  Intensely sweet honey, apple, caramel flavor.  Syrupy body.

Many thanks to Eclectic for this bottle. Pours out a slightly cloudy/ slightly clear orangy/amber color. Aroma is of oak, vanilla and some fruity notes, mainly sweet apple. Taste is complex, a fruity sweetness starts off and fades into a nice vanilla, oak flavor. Some Candi sugar going on in there and some other sweet fruit notes. Slight earthy oak flavor on the finish with a very slight alcoholic note. Other than the finish the alcohol is very well hidden, making this a very smooth beer.

3rd Annual Woodshop Tasting, 3/1/08. Thanks Chris!  Easy drinking and pleasant.  Very similar to the regular Damn in flavor, just smothered in oak and with a much softer carbonation and a lush mouthfeel.
Tasted at 2008 Woodshop hosted by cquiroga.  Yellow color.  Medium carbonation.  Bretty phenolics in the aroma. No sourness.  Kind of like an all-Brett beer.  Easy to drink.

Sampled at cquirogas 3rd Annual Woodshop Tasting, 3/1/08. Thanks again Chris! Another rarity I was stoked to see make an appearance. Clear blond color with a bubbly white head. Light fruity phenols of pear, coriander and Belgian-style yeasts loft off the surface. Pleasant flavor of banana, pear and clove similar to regular Damnation. The oak aging is faint, I was expecting more prominence. Easy finish with a thinned body. Pretty damn good, but I dont see it beating Damnation by much.
I tasted this beer at City Beer in San Francisco. It has the perfect balance between tart and oakey smoothness.

Managed to get a sample at the 3rd Woodshop tasting, thanks to cquiroga for opening. I like Damnation but this version adds so much more in complexity and is so smooth, I would certainly encourage Vinny to do this again - I want some bottles of my own. Yep.

This is not one of my favorite styles but this was dam tastey and enjoyable with a yellow look to it and a tiny and fading head.This beers ABV was present and the oaked flavor and smell was there, the finish was a little and yet smooth in its own way but i still like my dark strong beers more.CHEERS!

Clear golden/yellow body with a tiny beige head. Lightly sweet, oaky nose with vanilla, herbs, peach, pear and light pepper. Lightly sweet, spicy taste with lots of pepper, light cotton candy/honey, sweet oak and herbs. Medium/full body is soft with moderate, spritzy carbonation.
750ml bottle @Mels YEHA-pours a white head and yellow color.  Aroma is dry, spicy, wood.  Taste is dry, spicy, wood, medium malt, yeast.  Occasional.

sampled at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival Nov 2008, an event shared with what seemed liked hundreds of ratebeerians and enjoyed mostly through a straw, since my face was a bloody mess of scabs and stitches. this came from the RB table full of bottles. This was another of the amazing ice chest from John C. the aroma was very yeasty with hints of sweet fruit. the alcohol was very subtle and there was hints of cloves and fruit, it finished sweet smooth and clean. awesome!
Hazy pale yellow color. The aroma was malty sweet with lemon notes. The taste was sweet and spicy with yeast and banana flavors. Light wood in the after taste. Good stuff here.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 Two ratings of this one:  First time I had a bit of the bottom of the bottle, and I guess it was yeast-heavy because it was cloudy and the funk of the nose was fairly prominent.  It had a gassy funk to it, a really nice woody farmhouse scent along with some of the more expected clove, lemon, banana and candy sugar notes.  I was amazed by the dryness and tartness, but after sampling from another bottle a few months later, I could see that what I got was muddled by the yeast.  It was delectable, mind you, but it was still muddled.  So on to the second time I got to try this, thanks to eclectic for sharing a bottle.  The funk wasn’t there, I was so surprised, and instead it was some lightly sweet hay and lemon scents, very similar to the standard Damnation, with only a small wet/green wood note in the nose to indicate the use of oak chips.  Flavor-wise it was also a surprise, with some light dryness but nearly none of the funk or tartness that the yeast contained.  Rather, it was clean, crisp, and leaning slightly to the sweeter side of things, with a somewhat bland finish, and it left me a little deflated.

Bottle aquired from Goldtwins (Thanks) and cracked at YEHA.  Poured a cloudy straw yellow color body with a small white head.  The aroma is funky yeast, light citrus and bananas.  Flavors are sweet fruits, bananas, spices, barnyard, and a dry oak finish.

Bottle cbus-x shared by bdburdman, thanks again Brian. Yellow-orange pour with a white head. Aroma of oak, yeast, sweet malt, light fruits, subtle sour, lemon/lemonzest. Flavors of oak, lemon/light fruits, sweet pale malt. Medium-light body, woody/malty/sweet with a woody/sweet/dry/tart finish.
Cloudy straw color with no head.  Aroma of banana, yeast, and spice.  Taste-fruit, yeast, and wood.  Nice beer.

Bottle shared at C-bus 10 by bgburdman!!   Pours golden color with a thinnish white head.   Aroma is caramel, oak, yeast, some citrus.  Flavor is candi sugar, oak, vanilla, yeasty, spice.   Palate is medium to light, medium carboantion, finishes tart.   Nice.

750 ml bottle shared with toncatcher.  Hazy dark yellow with big head.  Some spice and citrus on the aroma.  Wood from the barrel in there too.  Flavor was similar with wood touches in the finish.  Spice up front with vanilla and hints of lemon.  Pretty tasty

Bottle shared at Madness. Pours a very hazy gold that leans towards a slight touch of brown with a small white bubbly head. Slight notes of wood, sour, funkiness and some lemon zest. Medium bodied with a very dry finish. Flavors of yeast, bread, and a slight touch of wood. Pretty good stuff, very well hidden alcohol.

750 shared at YEHA- Great appearance, very hazy golden in color with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma is quite strong- with plenty of musty yeast, phenolics, light notes of banana, and spices.  Taste:  fruit: banana, light pear, spicy, funky belgian yeast, candi sugar, light oak.  Pretty good, but the part I didnt enjoy was the fact that it was a bit alcoholic, and not as drinkable as some of my favorite tripels- Allagash, St Bernardus, etc.  If this was a percent and a half lower, I think I would have enjoyed it alot more.

750ml bottle. Poured a medium yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of yeast, fruity, citrus, wood, funky, and spices. Tastes of funky fruitiness, wood, spices, vanilla, and candi sugar sweetness.

C-bus 10.  Thanks to bgburdman for sharing.  Strong caramel malt aroma with belgian yeast.  Golden color with a light head.  Full palate.  Nice caramel malt flavor with plenty of belgian candi sugar and spices.  Interesting brew, but not my cup of tea.

2007 PP SAF Bottle brought by JohnC, many thanks! : Hazy golden hue with a fizzy head and some lace. The aroma is funky and cheesy, cherry and apricot esters, grassy and herbal, woody, hint of caramel. The taste has a nice balance of funk and citric acid along malty and yeasty base. A touch of honey and clove as well. The mouth feel is sprite and lively, very refreshing with a dry finish. A real winner, big but not over the top. A must try!

PP Strong Ale Fest 07, another killer bottle shared by JohnC.  Pours cloudy yellow with a 1 finger bright white head.  Nose is amazing, silly levels of citrus here.  Tatse is super fantastic. Sweet, well rounded killer killer triplel, if they all tasted like this Id love the style more, prob my favorite of this style Ive ever had.

Shared this at the pizza port strong ale fest.
smoth, creamy, tasty,sweet, this beer was Really good.

Bottle, courtesy of Eclectic. Glowing clear yellow with a white head. Grassy noble hops and oak in the nose, floral. Pretty sweet, lots of pale malt, then oak, lemon and some pear. No clovey, phenolic banana character. Some herbal hop presence. Full-bodied with moderate carbonation, not crisply carbonated. Nice beer but I prefer the standard Damnation.

Bottle sampled on 9/15/07: Pours a transparent deep golden with a wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of earthy musty oaky, doughy and sweet caramely Belgian malt and yeast.  Body starts fairly full and malty with good grassy slightly funky complexity and nice oaky woody balance toward a slightly warming enjoyable finish.  Very nice and quite drinkable.

(11/3/07, 750ml bottle, thanks eclectic) Small off-white head, hazy straw body.  Aroma is medium sweet, floral, yeasty, light brett.  Taste is medium sweet, yeast, lemon, floral, alcohol warming.  Medium-full body, moderately creamy, light acidity.

Body is a dark, murky amber with a fleeting fizzy head.  Aroma of a musty cellar, notes of spice, herbs, charred wood, sweet malt.  Light carbonation, oily mouthfeel.  Flavor was woody and musty.  Did not care for this one.

A little bit of sourness in the aroma, a lot of spices, but nothing overwhelming.  Just smells like a yummy beer.
Taste is initially a little sour, but develops into a spicy, sweet, not really-complex-but-good beer.
Finish is a little cloying and spicy.
Oh yeah, I forgot about the oak.  
The oak finishes well, but is not overwhelming, just adds some dryness to the beer.  
This beer is very solid.

Brought to the Champaign Urbana Beer Club November meeting. Thanks to Tom S. for passing along the bottle to me through his friend. Notes of lemon zest and hay on the nose lead into candied peel, honey, chamomile, ginger, sour cherry, and a touch of toasty oak. Its certainly solid and flavorful, but the finish was lacking as was the mouthfeel. Good, not overwhelming.

Bottled sample via my friend Trevor, and tasted side-by-side with the regular Damnation. Aromas of red licorice, vanilla, and apricot. More red licorice and vanilla in the mouth, along with notes of almond, citrusy hops, and alcohol. A bit heavier in the mouth than the regular Damnation, and with a light sour citrus note.

bottle at the not so aptly named "An Evening w/ Pantanap #1"...appearance: orange-brown pour with a fluffy white head....aroma: yeasty with fruity esthers. citrusy and bready....taste: sweet candied sugar, vanilla, and subtle spice notes.  much sweeter than expected which detracted from my enjoyment of th beer.

750 ml bottle sampled at "An Evening with Pantanap #1": thanks to kan for a chance to try this.  Pours a golden orange with an off white head.  Nose is yeasty and funky with florals and citrus.  Creamy sweet flavors.  Vanilla, orange, spice, pepper.  Tangy and overly sweet.

sampled at "An Evening with Pantanap #1": thanks to kan for this rare gem. 750ml bottle. pours dense golden with white head. nose is sweet, vanillay, flowery. flavor is really sweet grainy, toasted grain, vanilla, wow really sweet stuff. lacks character. too sweet, no alc noticed. very different from damnation and not nearly as good.

750mL bottle, courtesy of eclectic.  Thanks, Kevin!  Pours a cloudy, dull whitish-yellow color; whitish head with patchy lacing.  Dense, boozy yeast and yellow fruit and dough in the aroma; slightly warming.  Pleasant mouthfeel: dense Belgian sugar and toasty vanilla and warm, biscuity malts; lively carbonation; nice toasty oak and vanilla presence; a very different beer from the standard Damnation, and a bit more intricate and pleasant.  Lengthy, yeasty and belgian sugar finish; dry.

Poured from a 750.  Clear, tinny yellow appearance.  Butter, clove, spruce, and alcohol in a syrupy aroma; late hints of graham and sesame seed.  Flavor suffers under the weight of its heat; quiet sparks of mint, lemonade and pepper flash momentarily only to be quickly extinguished by the tranquilizing force of honey and alcohol.  Still, this is not offensively overpowering, however damaging it is to the complexity of the broader picture, rendering it uninteresting in its basic presentation.  Brisk in the mouth, while heavy.  Spice and dry wood finish; cardamom and oak.  Warm, somewhat difficult, and perhaps slightly overdone.  Thanks for sharing, Kevin!
Burnt fruit aroma, candy. Pours a cloudy orange with thin head. Sweetness, wood. Smooth dry finish. Alcohol is well hidden.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2009  Sure wish my wife hadnt drank half the bottle. Aroma of sweet candied, citrus fruits. Orange, dried pineapple and banana.  Some spice.  Very aromatic. Pours a murky yellow/orange with a thin white head. Excellent balance of dry and tart yeas and candied sweet fruit on the palate. Just a hint of lactic sourness. Slightly floral . Medium to full bodied. Creamy. Lively carbonation. Finishes with a nice tartness. This stuff better start to get distributed  in Minnesota,  or Im going to have to do a lot more trades with Richard because my  wife wants more of this  beer.

Sweet and oak forward nose with a touch of almond blossom and vanilla. Very sweet upfront with a big vanilla and spice component. Slightly honeyed on the palate. Sweet and spicy finish with a touch of citrus zest.

Big thanks to MikeTD for this badboy. Hazy orange pour, medium white head. Aroma is earthy and phenolic belgian yeast. Flavor is spicy. Orange, coriander, clove, honey, cinnamon and a touch of nutmeg. Sweet sugary, floral, perfumy, its all there. A big spicy phenolic sugary taste to sum it up. A touch of wood in the aftertaste but I think it brings out different flavors rather than just oak. Full mouthfeel, lots of carbonation, full on belgian. As it warms the oak sourness does come out more.

25.4 ounce bottle all to myself at Toronado (by the time I finished this, I was shitfaced).    Aroma initially is very wine like--almost smells like a cabernet.  Quite vinous with woody, oak, and vanilla hints.  Some lightly banana-like yeasty easters are also appreciated with some butterscotch present, too.  Interesting aroma that is pleasant.  Mildly hazy honey- colored body with a moderately frothy off-white head.  Killer lacking makes this a 4/5.  Has that mellow, lightly sweet, vanilla, oaky flavor to start.  Some marshmellows are also present along with sweet, caramelly, chewy, nutty malt flavors in the middle.  Finishes with a little butterscotch.  Great mouthfeel.  I was skeptical of this beer and all of the hype, but this beer just hits many chords for me.  The only drawback I found (after drinking 25 oz) is that it can be a little cloying when consumed in quantity.

Poured a hazy gold color with an almost white head.  The aroma was yeasty and woody with sweet malt.  Semi-sweet flavor with notes of vanilla and wood.  Estery finish but drys out.  Lightly spicy as it warms.

Yellow gold in color with a full head.  Unimpressive nose.  Flavor seems to have a fairly agressive hop character, with some herbaceous and lemon notes.  Also, its sweet with some fruit-like flavors.  The oak provides a fairly nice component, though clearly the oak influence would be more enjoyable, had it been aged in an actual barrel.  Lots of heat and definately not a lot of subtlety.  The finish could be longer as well, it fades quick.  Just seems rough and unrefined, it lacks depth.

Many thanks to goldtwins for bringing this one out.  Pale golden beer with a thick white head.  Lightly hazed.  Beautiful fruity/spice aroma, apple/pear, soft lean pale Belgian malts.  Bready yeastiness and loads of fresh spice and herbal mintiness.  Loads of wheaty aroma with a hint of vanilla accenting the lean pale malts.  Oak is quite subtle.  The mintiness that I love about RR beers is here in abundance.  Light lemon and citrus... incredible complexity and balance.  Wood is very subtle but I love it nonetheless.  I hope I can get my hands on another bottle of this.

(12oz bottle) Sampled at the Post-Great Canadian Beer Festival 2007 in Victoria on September 8th, 2007. Courtesy of Enniskillen. Lasting white head with a cloudy amber body. Pours a woody mint with white pepper nose. Flavour is orange and nicely wild n yeasty.

Bottle from Toronado. Slightly hazy golden, moderate to small head, some lacing and retention. Aroma is hugely oaked and takes away from the big spice notes of the regular version. Flavor is better, oakey sweetness with some light spice and sugar notes. Alcohol is hidden perfectly. Fairly sweet with a medium body. Very enjoyable, but doesnt offer much more (if any) complexity.

Many thanks to goldtwins for sharing (you the man, Larry!) - hazy gold, with a smallis ring of lace - mild oak in the aroma, with strong wintery spices - moderate oak in the flavor, with vanilla and strong spice playing well alcohol warmth - the alcohol starts to overpower a little after a while - as beastie notes, it has a strong, belgian sweetness/fruity character to it, but not a lot else besides the oak - a decent belgian ale, but not very tripel-ish, and not nearly as good as the regular damnation.

Shared by goldtwins twice now, this time at JoeMcPhees at CaptainCougar comes to NY gathering.  Pours a thick murky golden, looks good.  Aoma is overly spicy/phenols with a certain muddled aspect - maybe its oak but it comes off as stale ground earthiness.  This gets in the way of the nice Belgian sweetness below that. The taste however has a lot of strong Belgian sweetness but its not backed up by much else. Some nice light esters though and has an above average carbonation. Very mediocre for Russian River.

text: Bottle Cloudy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. Pale grains, white oak, fuzzy fruits and whispers of camphor and alcohol constitute the nose. The flavor is earthy, boozy and bitter with lots of live, white oak up front and lesser notes of vanilla and butterscotch arising as it warms. Just a hint of pale malt sweetness. Full-bodied and oily with moderate carbonation. Finishes creamy, malty and wonderfully bitter. Thanks to mgumby10 for sharing his bottle of this rarity!

Pours cloudy gold with mellow orange hues and a thin, pure white head. Slow recession, not quite fully for a long while. The aroma is that of an incredibly sweet tripel, first and foremost. Candi sugar leaps from the glass by the pound. Alcohol is strong and fruity. Oak is very intense, never overdone but definitely not shy. Hops are herbal and grassy and wet, full-on and adequate in amount. Notes of mixed fruit basket is moderate but leans toward heavy. The flavor has very good depth, much more than a standard tripel or trhe average oak aged Belgian whatever. Incredible development of subtleties starts immediately, malt extraction is far and away finished. Pineapple floats just above the rest of the flavor and nods in and out. Highly sugary-sweet - but sugars are very complex and admirably placed within. Wood character is exceedingly deep and only lightly tannic, just fresh. Bitterness is low, astringency low, acidity low-mild. The finish is mildly sweet but quickly becomes off-dry and candy coated. The mouthfeel is medium-full bodied and tangentially wild, extremely complex, buttery, slippery but firm like beer jello, spicy, comforting, blanketing and velvety. Not incredible but this is no joke either, very good and as always: Russian River delivers a very drinkable and authentic beer. This outing has a distinctly American twist that is neither hit or miss for my palate, just another wood-aged beer that happens to be tasty.

Courtesy mgumby10. Hazy gold and a small, foamy white head. Aroma of candy sweet malt, buttery oak, floral hops, lightly zesty yeast. Flavor adds some oaky chardonnay like elements, light white bread, and a little acidity in the finish. Full body, balanced carbonation. Great tripel.

Mgumby hooks it up again!!!  Pours a hazy golden, orange.  Aroma is fruity, which was not expected at all.  There is a definite oaked component, dancing gracefully with a touch of alcohol.   Flavor is impressive.  Some Belgian notes, but definitely a variation on a theme.  Very nice.

Courtesy irishboy.  Thanks again Richard!!  Pours a cloudy orange color with a small white head.  Smells pretty spicy, with touches of candy sugar, and a definite oakiness.  The oak seems to be the most prominent aroma.  The flavor was very creamy with a nice little candy sugar spice to it.  The alcohol was apparent, but not up in your face.  Seems to be masked quite well.  The finish was slightly sweet, with some spice and candy sugar characters as well.  Definitely interesting and more complex than the regular Damnation.  Very nice and pretty easy drinking for such a big beer.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2011 2011 rating, bottle.  Hazy straw gold.  The aroma is very fruity with light spice and oak.  Almost fresca-like character with the citrus character.  Dries it out a bit, the oak chips.2007 rating:  Murky appearance.  Woody, slightly boozy aroma with distinct notes of firm, malty and briskly-hopped tripel.  Firm and warming from the alcohol.  Some oak character, and fairly robust hop accents.  Fun, but maybe not the best output from RR. 7-4-7-4-14 = 3.4
Bottle shared at CapFlus tasting after GCBF. Light Saison nose. Cloudy yellow. Foamy head. Alcohol body. Very drinkable light Saison/Tripel. Not clean. Candy sugar touches.

Bottled. Beer is clear, light tawny brown. Head is initally small, off-white, frothy, quickly diminishing but lasting. Specks of lacing on the snifter.

First impression on the nose is citric, estery and oaky. Malty with light notes of toasted grain, cookie, thin caramel; Hoppy with light/moderate notes of lemon zest, moderate resinous herbal; Yeasty with a light note of faintly sweaty basement, light /moderate notes of banana/clove, bubblegum; Light note of spicy alcohol, oak.

The flavor is moderately/heavily sweet, lightly/moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, warm, lightly acidic, lightly sweet, light/moderately bitter finish. Doesnt seem like 11%.

The body is medium, the texture is watery/velvety and the carbonation is lively.

All in all, quite fetching but not stunning.

Bottle. Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (herbs), lightly yeasty (basement), with notes of alcohol, charred wood and ash, canned pineapple. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic. Sorry, despite my typical love for Belgian brews from Vinnie (including recent batches of Damnation), this is a miss for me. The opposite of bright...dull aromas of damp cement, alcohol, that canned pineapple smell that too-old Belgian golden ales seem to get, and burnt wood. I like my tripels and strong goldens to be brighter and fresher smelling. Very hot finish, which makes it a little hard to drink. Pretty good balance, but eh, just not digging this at all.

Bottle from... wait its a secret! He told me not to say. ;)

Had during a blind tasting with four other tripels. It was immediately obvious which one this was. The oak is prominent and lovely, and the unforgettable aroma of the normal damnation was apparent and lovely.  Smelling this beer is like heaven. Oak, bready yeast, light spices... deep with aromas I have never smelled, and bursting with fresh aromas of some of my favorite foods. Brilliant. Much like normal damnation, the flavor is not quite up to par, but in this beer it is a lot better, with rich oak notes, spicy belgian yeast and good christmas type flavors... pine, berries, cinnamon. Not too harsh on the palate for an 11% tripel, though I certainly wouldnt call it very drinkable. This is a world class beer, and is very enjoyable. Thanks, person who sent this to me!

From a 750mL Bottle.  Pours a crystal clear color of pale gold, topped with a quickly dissipating head of fizzy, sudsy white.  Loads of vanilla.  Notes of oak and mild pineapple fruitiness add some complexity to the nose, but the vanilla character is quite strong.   A mild yeasty spice adds more desirable depth, while a touch of boozey character warns of the high ABV.  Medium bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel.  Exceptionally clean and for lack of a better description, tastes well executed.  The flavors start out with some apricot brandy dried with a hint of oak.  This opens up to some yeasty spice and soothing vanilla.  A peppery spice lingers in the final smack.  Finish is a touch hot, but not offensive.  I like this.  Its a bit boozey, but otherwise perfectly executed.  The vanilla character and yeast spiciness are quite pleasing and an excellent ante up for this rendition of Damnation.  Thanks, Dr. Bill!

Bottle Deep golden in color with a little white head. Yeasty spicy aroma. Peppery citrusy notes. Hoppy and malty flavor. Very smooth tasting and not too sweet. Spicy lemony floral notes.  Finish is spicy. Medium bodied. Very drinkable. Wow. Really a great beer. Wish we could get more.

Bottle. Holy shit is what comes to mind here. Just a great looking beer as the head lasts and lasts. The first thing I notice is the subtle use of orange and tangerine. Sweet without being cloying. Dry without feeling like the Sahara. Soft, like silk, this is an amazing beer.

Yellow gold. Frothy white head yields patchy lace as it slowly subsides. Bright and perfumey aromas of honey-caramelized bananas, coriander, straw, and refined oak. Taffylike yeast character. Aromas are just glowing. Soothingly soft carbonation. A succulent and dense fruitiness immediately unfolds on the palate and is soon met by a supple explosion of lemon, floral hops, and peppery alcohol which accentuates the sweet and spicy clove and coriander. Nutty oak slices through the slick fruitiness and densely juicy core in a scratchy yet clean fashion, but is brilliantly utilized and understated and harmonizes with the ever-building lush foundation of chewy straw. Alcohol imparts a spicy dryness, but is otherwise nary a factor. Clean as a whistle, overall, and impeccably attenuated. Orangey roundness adds to the refinement and bolsters the drinkability. Yeast adds structure as well as a cheesy and taffylike creaminess which absorbs much of the alcoholic warmth. Exceptionally polished oak lends bounce rather than grit to the body. Hop character is remarkably soft, floral, spicy and juicy. Dazzling interplay between the juicy oak and rich straw. Finishes moistly full and warming with exemplary integration between the oak, pie-crust malts, green banana, honeysuckle, and vanilla taffy which is delivered via the combo of oak and yeast. Love the unique spin on the original Damnation. Compared to the 4-5 batches of Damnation Ive experienced, this edges them out by a thin margin. Alcohol seems less apparent than the standard batches, which are significantly lower in alcohol than this, and thats yet another testament to Vinnies masterfulness. A successful rendition Ill say.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle from IrishBoy.  Trying after watching the movie The Number 23.  Its an interesting number.  Color is a very light amber, with a very thin white head.  Aroma is apples, nutmeg, yeast, oak, vanilla.  Taste is a heavy vanilla and oak content followed by the traditional Damnation spiciness of nutmeg and cloves; has a light content of alcohol which comes across in a positive way, has a llight sweetness in the end also.  This just makes me understand why Russian River is my far and away favorite brewery.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 Quite oak-like in the aroma, but it is not overpowering & in fact took me a second to recognize.  The beer is a brilliantly clear, copper tinged, gold color and is topped by a frothy, initially two-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head.  Aromatic notes of buttery oak, vanillin, orange zest, and a light, yet sharp, spicy oak character.  The hints of vanilla and orange remind me a bit of an orange-cream candy, though the aroma is fairly dry smelling.  Boozy notes of warm alcohol are present, especially if you linger too long over the nose.  Slightly must, but overall the aroma is nice, but not all that striking.  It actually might not be the alcohol alone that is noticeable, but really a lot of the spicy oak character that is accentuating a sharpness / hotness in the aromatic finish.

The taste is quite a bit sweeter than the aroma suggested, but it is well within line for a beer of this strength.  The sweetness accentuates a note of orange / lemon zest.  This beer is actually fairly dry over all & becomes lightly sweet as my palate adjusts to it.  The beer finishes with a mix of hot, higher alcohols, bitter hops, some light phenolics & spicy oak character.  The oak / barrel character is quite a bit more subtle than the aroma would have suggested, which in my opinion is a good thing.  Oak notes of vanillin, spicy, woody oak and a touch of tannic astringency are all noticeable if you dig a bit, but really they contribute to the overall character of this beer.  Really the oak, while not hugely apparent individually, does have a large effect on the flavor profile of this beer (from the vanilla notes, the spicy character, to the perception of bitterness, astringency & alcohol in the finish).  Floral notes of honeysuckle, orange blossom and bird of paradise add an interesting component to the flavor profile.  The residual sugars provide a nice, softly creamy, heft to this beer that makes this beer contemplative; it is nothing like a chewy, all malt beer (like a Barleywine), as it is fairly light for its strength.  In fact, at times it is down right drinkable; I think a big part of this is that the carbonation helps to refresh and lighten up the overall perception of this beer.

This beer definitely is strong, while the 10.5% does not quite hit you over the head, it is still noticeable.  I really am enjoying the soft, orange like flavors & aromas in this beer; these notes pair quite well with some of the oak components.  I have a feeling this beer will age quite well for a long time.  In fact, this beer really needs to age for quite some time as it is a bit too young right now; perhaps a year but maybe even three would do this beer wonders  To tell you the truth, I wouldnt be surprised if this peaked at 5 or 10 years even.  It is certainly not a bad tipple right now, it is just that I see this getting a lot better.

750 ml bottle shared at Columbus Tasting 8 from Irishboy! - thanks Richard! - Pours amber with a short white head and a fair amount of lace.  Aromas of yeast, oak, and some vanilla.  Flavor is oaky with some yeast, bread, and that always present Russian River tartness.  Smooth and easy drinking with good carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.  Nicely done..

Bread, fruit and wood blending together to remind me of a light spiced, pickled peach aroma. Hazy color of ripe peach flesh with a white head that flattened but laces a little. Medium bodied. Moderate, creamy carbonation. Its definitely sweet and spicy. The peachy fruit brings back that spiced peach memory. I think we called them pickled, but they were not sour; too much sugar. Anyway, the oak sort of astringates* the mouth, and the bitter just pushes the sensation further. There is a low key medicinal phenolic note as the other flavors diminish. The oak seems to last the longest. This is the most exceptionally drinkable ale. Phew.  
*Improper creation of verb form?

C-Bus 8 - Bottle shared by OhioDad: Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. Aroma, oaky, yeasty, some hints of vanilla, and bready. Flavor, pale malts, some slight oaky notes, tart, with some lighter fruits. Very nice.

Pale orange with moderate, fine head. Moderate oakey aroma with some spiky citrusness and leafy, peachy yeastiness. Woodiness is subdued and vaguely earthy rather than sharp and singular. Playfully tart at the beginning of the sip, apples, peaches, light phenols, hot bitterness. Warm, agreeable long-lasting finish, slowly titrating bitterness. Lots of tart aromatics tingle your nostrils.

Bottle.  Pineapple-lemon color.  Hazy, yeasty, bottom of the bottle sample, Im afraid (I was last in line).  Oak, wooden, sour apple.  Dry, tangy, paint-thinner like ripple in the nostrils, but in a good way if that makes sense.

Bottle from City Beer Store.  Hazy yellow color, aroma and taste of banana, very light oak, vanilla, yeast.  Quite malty but has a west coast IPA hop tinge, sweet.  Very refreshing, almost candy-like at times.  Dont share, have the whole bottle for yourself!

Bottle shared by eclectic at BCTC 07.  Thanks Kevin!  Poured a hazy golden yellow with a good sized white head and lacing that lasts throughout. Aroma is oak, spices, lemon, banana, earthy yeast, vanilla, and a mild hoppiness. Flavor is equally spicey and fruity and you can really taste the oak chips and vanilla, though they dont detract from the other flavors.  Pretty smooth for the abv, though some alcohol could be noted. Nice beer, but Id probably prefer it without the oak chip aging.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2007 [BCTC 07] Poured a hazy golden color with a  medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, citrus fruits, spices, banana, some honey, and a floral hoppiness.  Taste of citrus, banana, orange peel, tropical fruit, subdued vanilla oak, more honey, and a dry, bitter, hoppy finish. Some alcohol noted as well. Thanks eclectic!

Draft. Golden amber beer with a nice whitish head. Malt, spice, and slight estery fruit aroma. Big oak, vanilla flavor with bubblegum, spicy yeast, and malt. Lingering vanilla, oak, and spice. Medium body, Alcohol present, but not overpowering. Some summer fruitiness. Good beer, but a bit too much vanilla for my tastes.

On Tap at the Toronado.  Very light vanilla oak flavor - definitely not strong wood or oak flavors.  Damnation on steroids.  Lots of the same appearance characteristics, a little more hop presence, but definitely still a very dry and clean beer.  Awesome earthy, plum like fruity esters from the yeast - probably from Russian Rivers proprietary WLP500-like yeast.   Very excellent beer.

Bottle.  Golden copper color with a frothy ivory head.  Somewhat oaky nose with tons of fruit; bananas, strawberries and apricots.  The oak is very understated.  Malty and a bit sweet with more banana notes.  Tons of apples in the flavor.  Lingering finish and slightly hot.  This beer rocks!

(on tap @ the brewpub)slightly darker in color than the original damnation.i got a small white head with my pour.nose and flavor are loaded with vanilla and oak.(but not in an obnoxious way)followed by fruits,belgian yeast and candy.very nicely done vinnie!

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2014 Draft at the brewpub, Batch 023; Thanks to Vinnie for a great beer! Nice and hazy yellow-gold in color with a medium yellowish head that heavily laces the glass! Nose of apricots, oakiness, apple, with some light nutmeg and clove notes; Flavor showed a general light fruitiness (apricot, apple and some lemon) along with a mild hop bitterness to the finish.
